revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=January 2010}} ''' SOLiD ''' (Sequencing by Oligonucleotide Ligation and Detection) is a [[Single-molecule sequencing|next-generation DNA sequencing]] technology developed by [[Life Technologies (Thermo Fisher Scientific)|Life Technologies]] and has been commercially available since 2006. This next generation technology generates hundreds of millions to billions of small sequence reads at one time.
This method should not be confused with "sequencing by synthesis," a principle used by Roche-454 [[pyrosequencing]] (introduced in 2005, generating millions of 200-400bp reads in 2009), and the [[Solexa]] system (now owned by Illumina) (introduced in 2006, generating hundreds of millions of 50-100bp reads in 2009)
These methods have reduced the cost from $0.01/base in 2004 to nearly $0.0001/base in 2006 and increased the sequencing capacity from 1,000,000 bases/machine/day in 2004 to more than 5,000,000,000 bases/machine/day in 2009. Over 30 publications exist describing its use first for nucleosome positioning from Valouev et al.,<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors =Valouev A, Ichikawa J, Tonthat T |title=A high-resolution, nucleosome position map of C. elegans reveals a lack of universal sequence-dictated positioning |journal=Genome Research |volume=18 |issue=7 |pages=1051–63 |date=July 2008 |pmid=18477713 |pmc=2493394 |doi=10.1101/gr.076463.108|display-authors=etal}}</ref> transcriptional profiling or strand sensitive RNA-Seq with Cloonan et al.,<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors =Cloonan N, Forrest AR, Kolle G |title=Stem cell transcriptome profiling via massive-scale mRNA sequencing |journal=Nature Methods |volume=5 |issue=7 |pages=613–9 |date=July 2008 |pmid=18516046 |doi=10.1038/nmeth.1223|display-authors=etal}}</ref> single cell transcriptional profiling with Tang et al.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors =Tang F, Barbacioru C, Wang Y |title=mRNA-Seq whole-transcriptome analysis of a single cell |journal=Nature Methods |volume=6 |issue=5 |pages=377–82 |date=May 2009 |pmid=19349980 |doi=10.1038/nmeth.1315|display-authors=etal}}</ref> and ultimately human resequencing with McKernan et al.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors =McKernan KJ, Peckham HE, Costa GL |title=Sequence and structural variation in a human genome uncovered by short-read, massively parallel ligation sequencing using two-base encoding |journal=Genome Research |volume=19 |issue=9 |pages=1527–41 |date=September 2009 |pmid=19546169 |pmc=2752135 |doi=10.1101/gr.091868.109|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
The method used by this machine (sequencing-by-ligation) has been reported to have some issue sequencing palindromic sequences.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = Yu-Feng Huang | author-link = Yu-Feng Huang | author2 = Sheng-Chung Chen | author2-link = Sheng-Chung Chen | author3 = Yih-Shien Chiang | author3-link = Yih-Shien Chiang | author4 = Tzu-Han Chen | author4-link = Tzu-Han Chen | author24 = Kuo-Ping Chiu | author24-link = Kuo-Ping Chiu | last-author-amp = yes | title = Palindromic sequence impedes sequencing-by-ligation mechanism | journal = [[BMC Systems Biology]] | volume = 6 Suppl 2 | pages = S10 | year = 2012 |doi = 10.1186/1752-0509-6-S2-S10 | pmid = 23281822 | pmc=3521181 }}</ref>
==Chemistry== A library of DNA fragments is prepared from the sample to be sequenced, and is used to prepare clonal bead populations. That is, only one species of fragment will be present on the surface of each magnetic bead. The fragments attached to the magnetic beads will have a universal P1 adapter sequence attached so that the starting sequence of every fragment is both known and identical. Emulsion [[PCR]] takes place in microreactors containing all the necessary reagents for PCR. The resulting PCR products attached to the beads are then covalently bound to a glass slide.
Primers hybridize to the P1 adapter sequence within the library template. A set of four fluorescently labelled di-base probes compete for ligation to the sequencing primer. Specificity of the di-base probe is achieved by interrogating every 1st and 2nd base in each ligation reaction. Multiple cycles of ligation, detection and cleavage are performed with the number of cycles determining the eventual read length. Following a series of ligation cycles, the extension product is removed and the template is reset with a primer complementary to the n-1 position for a second round of ligation cycles.
Five rounds of primer reset are completed for each sequence tag. Through the primer reset process, each base is interrogated in two independent ligation reactions by two different primers. For example, the base at read position 5 is assayed by primer number 2 in ligation cycle 2 and by primer number 3 in ligation cycle 1.
==Throughput & Accuracy== According to ABI, the SOLiD 3plus platform yields 60 gigabases of usable DNA data per run. Due to the two base encoding system, an inherent accuracy check is built into the technology and offers 99.94% accuracy. The chemistry of the systems also means that it is not hindered by homopolymers unlike the Roche 454 FLX system and so large and difficult homopolymer repeat regions are no longer a problem to sequence.
==Applications== Naturally the technology will be used to sequence DNA, but because of the high parallel nature of all next generation technologies they also have applications in [[transcriptomics]] and [[epigenomics]].
[[DNA microarray|Microarrays]] was once the mainstay of the transcriptomics the last ten years and array based technology has subsequently branched out to other areas. However, they are limited in that only information can be obtained for probes that are on the chip. Only information for organisms for which chips are available can obtained, and they come with all the problems of hybridizing large numbers of molecules (differing hybridizing temperatures). RNA-Seq transcriptomics by next gen sequencing will mean these barriers no longer hold true. Any organism's entire transcriptome could be potentially sequenced in one run (for very small bacterial genomes) and not only would the identification of each transcript be available but expression profiling is possible as quantitative reads can also be achieved.
[[Chromatin immunoprecipitation]] (ChIP) is a method for determining transcription factor binding sites and DNA-protein interactions. It has in the past been combined with array technology (ChIP-chip) with some success. Next gen sequencing can also be applied in this area. Methylation immunoprecipitation (MeDIP) can also be performed and also on arrays.
The ability to learn more about methylation and TF binding sites on a genome wide scale is a valuable resource and could teach us much about disease and molecular biology in general.
==See also== *[[2 Base Encoding]] *[[Next-generation sequencing]] *[[Applied Biosystems]] *[[Illumina (company)]] *[[454 Life Sciences]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *{{cite journal |author =Mardis ER |title=Next-generation DNA sequencing methods |journal=Annual Review of Genomics and Human Genetics |volume=9 |issue= |pages=387–402 |year=2008 |pmid=18576944 |doi=10.1146/annurev.genom.9.081307.164359}} *{{cite journal |author =Mardis ER |title=New strategies and emerging technologies for massively parallel sequencing: applications in medical research |journal=Genome Medicine |volume=1 |issue=4 |page=40 |year=2009 |pmid=19435481 |pmc=2684661 |doi=10.1186/gm40}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Abi Solid Sequencing}} [[Category:DNA sequencing]] [[Category:Biotechnology]]

revision.text:
'''African Palliative Care Association (APCA)''' is a [[pan-Africanism|pan-African]] [[non-governmental organization]] (NGO) working to promote and support the integration of [[palliative care]] into health systems across Africa. APCA has appeared on the BBC World Service,<ref>{{cite web|last=BBC World Service|title=Palliative Care Worldwide|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p00llmsx|accessdate=29 May 2013}}</ref> The Guardian<ref>{{cite news|last=The Guardian|title=Today in Healthcare|url=https://www.theguardian.com/healthcare-network/2013/mar/20/today-in-healthcare-20-march#block-5149cfe295cbaf64024f6435|accessdate=29 May 2013|location=London|date=20 March 2013}}</ref> and across regional and national African press<ref>{{cite web|last=APCA|title=APCA in the press|url=http://www.africanpalliativecare.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=112&Itemid=111|accessdate=29 May 2013}}</ref> advocating for better palliative care provision.
== History ==
APCA was founded in Cape Town in 2002 after 28 palliative care trainers from across Africa met together and discussed the need for regional cooperation. The group produced the Cape Town Declaration,<ref>{{cite journal|title=The Palliative Care Trainers Declaration of Cape Town November 13, 2002|journal=Journal of Palliative Medicine|date=July 7, 2004|volume= 6|issue=: 3|pages=339–340|doi=10.1089/109662103322144637|url=http://online.liebertpub.com/doi/abs/10.1089/109662103322144637|accessdate=29 May 2013}}</ref> which holds palliative care, pain and symptom control as a human right for every adult and child with life-limiting illnesses.<ref>{{cite web|last=APCA|title=About us|url=http://www.africanpalliativecare.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=99&Itemid=20|accessdate=29 May 2013}}</ref> APCA however was not formally founded until two years later in 2004.<ref>{{cite web|last=True Colours Trust|title=Partners: APCA|url=http://www.truecolourstrust.org.uk/palliative-care-in-africa/african-palliative-care-association/|accessdate=29 May 2013}}</ref>
Since then APCA has continued to state palliative care as a human right, working with Human Rights Watch<ref>{{cite web|last=Human Rights Watch|title=Easing Africa's Pain: The Need for Palliative Care|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2013/05/16/easing-africas-pain-need-palliative-care|accessdate=29 May 2013}}</ref> and the Open Society Foundation,<ref>{{cite web|last=Open Society Foundation|title=Palliative Care is a human right|url=http://www.opensocietyfoundations.org/publications/palliative-care-human-right-fact-sheet|accessdate=29 May 2013}}</ref> calling on governments to live up to their responsibilities.
== Published material ==
* ''A Palliative Care Handbook for Africa'', available on the World Health Association's website<ref>{{cite web|last=The WHO|title=Resources|url=http://apps.who.int/medicinedocs/en/m/abstract/Js19115en/}}</ref> * ''Beating Pain. A Pocket Guide to Pain Management in Africa'', in cooperation with AID-STAR ONE<ref>{{cite web|last=AID-STAR ONE|title=APCA resources|url=http://www.aidstar-one.com/focus_areas/care_and_support/palliative_care_and_pain_management|accessdate=29 May 2013}}</ref> * ''Palliative Care for Women living with HIV and Cervical Cancer'', in cooperation with the Open Society Initiative for Southern Africa<ref>{{cite web|last=OSISA|title=Palliative care for women living with HIV|url=http://www.osisa.org/other/hiv-and-aids/regional/palliative-care-women-living-hiv|accessdate=29 May 2013}}</ref>
APCA also provides the editorial oversight to the Africa edition of ''ehospice news'',<ref>{{cite web|last=Ehospice|title=About us|url=http://www.ehospice.com/africa/en-gb/aboutus.aspx|accessdate=29 May 2013}}</ref> an online global palliative care news platform.
== Notable staff ==
Dr. Emmanuel Luyirika is the current executive director of APCA. He took up this position in August 2012. Before moving to APCA, Dr. Luyirika worked as clinical director, centre director and ultimately country director for Mildmay International in Uganda.<ref>{{cite web|last=ehospice|title=Merging medicine and management, Dr Emmanuel Luyirika|url=http://www.ehospice.com/africa/ArticlesList/MergingmedicineandmanagementDrEmmanuelLuyirika/tabid/1970/ArticleId/670/language/en-GB/View.aspx#.UaW7ZtIwdw8|accessdate=29 May 2013}}</ref>
Dr. Faith Mwangi-Powell was the founding director of APCA and held that position until 2012. Since then she has gone on to become the senior program officer for global advocacy with the International Palliative Care Initiative of the Open Society Foundations. Dr. Faith holds a Ph.D. in women's health and development and has published over 20 peer reviewed papers.<ref>{{cite web|last=The Open Society Foundation |title=Staff |url=http://www.opensocietyfoundations.org/people/faith-mwangi-powell |accessdate=29 May 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121020023954/http://www.opensocietyfoundations.org/people/faith-mwangi-powell |archivedate=20 October 2012 }}</ref>
== References ==
{{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{short description|A large South American bird in the New World vulture family }} {{Redirect|Vultur|the birds known as vultures|Vulture}} {{pp-move-indef}} {{speciesbox | name = Andean condor | fossil_range = {{Fossil range|2.6|0}}<small>Late [[Pliocene]]–[[Holocene]]</small> | image = Vultur gryphus -Doué-la-Fontaine Zoo, France-8a.jpg | image_caption = Female at Doué-la-Fontaine Zoo, France | image2 = AndeanCondorMale.jpg | image2_caption = Male at the [[Cincinnati Zoo]] | status = NT | status_system = IUCN3.1 | status_ref = <ref name=IUCN>{{IUCN|id=22697641 |title=''Vultur gryphus'' |assessor=BirdLife International |assessor-link=BirdLife International |version=2013.2 |year=2012 |accessdate=26 November 2013}}</ref> | genus = Vultur | parent_authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|Linnaeus]], [[10th edition of Systema Naturae|1758]] | species = gryphus | authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|Linnaeus]], [[10th edition of Systema Naturae|1758]] | synonyms = * ''Vultur fossilis'' <small>[[Francisco Moreno|Moreno]] & Mercerat, 1891</small> * ''Vultur patruus'' <small>[[Einar Lönnberg|Lönnberg]], 1902</small> * ''Vultur pratruus'' <small>Emslie, 1988 (''lapsus'')</small> | range_map = AndeanMap.png | range_map_caption = Yellow – approximate range/distribution }}
The '''Andean condor''' (''Vultur gryphus'') is a South American bird in the [[New World vulture]] family [[Cathartidae]] and is the only member of the [[genus]] '''''Vultur'''''. Found in the [[Andes]] mountains and adjacent Pacific coasts of western South America, the Andean condor is the largest flying bird in the world by combined measurement of weight and wingspan. It has a maximum wingspan of {{convert|3.3|m|ftin|abbr=on}}{{sfn|Richard P. Reading|Brian Miller|2000}} exceeded only by the wingspans of four [[seabirds]] and [[water birds]]—the roughly {{convert|3.5|m|ftin|abbr=on}} maximum of the [[wandering albatross]], [[southern royal albatross]], [[great white pelican]] and [[Dalmatian pelican]].<ref name="Ferguson-Lees">{{cite book | last = Ferguson-Lees | first = James | author2 = Christie, David A. | title = Raptors of the World | publisher = Houghton Mifflin | year = 2001 | location = Boston | isbn = 0-618-12762-3}}</ref>
It is a large black vulture with a ruff of white feathers surrounding the base of the neck and, especially in the male, large white patches on the wings. The head and neck are nearly featherless, and are a dull red color, which may flush and therefore change color in response to the bird's emotional state. In the male, there is a wattle on the neck and a large, dark red [[Comb (anatomy)|comb]] or caruncle on the crown of the head. Unlike most [[bird of prey|birds of prey]], the male is larger than the female.
The condor is primarily a [[scavenger]], feeding on [[carrion]]. It prefers large carcasses, such as those of [[deer]] or [[cattle]]. It reaches sexual maturity at five or six years of age and [[Bird nest|nests]] at elevations of up to {{convert|5000|m|ft|abbr=on}}, generally on inaccessible rock ledges. One or two eggs are usually laid. It is one of the world's longest-living birds, with a lifespan of over 70 years in some cases.
The Andean condor is a national symbol of [[Argentina]], [[Bolivia]], [[Chile]], [[Colombia]], [[Ecuador]], and [[Peru]] and plays an important role in the [[folklore]] and [[mythology]] of the Andean regions. The Andean condor is considered [[Near Threatened|near threatened]] by the [[IUCN]].<ref name=IUCN/> It is threatened by habitat loss and by [[secondary poisoning]] from carcasses killed by hunters. [[Captive breeding]] programs have been instituted in several countries.
==Taxonomy and systematics== The Andean condor was described by [[Sweden|Swedish]] scientist [[Carl Linnaeus]] in 1758 in the [[10th edition of Systema Naturae|tenth edition]] of his ''[[Systema Naturae]]'' and retains its original [[binomial nomenclature|binomial]] name of ''Vultur gryphus''.<ref>{{cite book | last=Linnaeus | first=C | authorlink=Carl Linnaeus | title=Systema naturae per regna tria naturae, secundum classes, ordines, genera, species, cum characteribus, differentiis, synonymis, locis. Tomus I. Editio decima, reformata. | quote = V. maximus, carúncula verticali longitudine capitis. | publisher=Laurentii Salvii | place=Holmiae (Stockholm) | url=https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/726991 | year=1758| page=86 | language=Latin }}</ref> The Andean condor is sometimes called the Argentinean condor, Bolivian condor, Chilean condor, Colombian condor, Ecuadorian condor, or Peruvian condor after one of the nations to which it is native. The generic term ''Vultur'' is directly taken from the [[Latin]] ''vultur'' or ''voltur'', which means "vulture".<ref>{{cite book | last = Simpson | first = D.P. | title = Cassell's Latin Dictionary | publisher = Cassell Ltd. | year = 1979 | edition = 5th | location = London | page = 883 | isbn = 0-304-52257-0}}</ref> Its specific epithet is derived from a variant of the [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] word γρυπός (''grupós'', "hook-nosed").<ref>{{cite book|last=Liddell| first=Henry George|author2=Robert Scott|year=1980|title=Greek-English Lexicon, Abridged Edition |publisher=Oxford University Press|location= Oxford|isbn= 0-19-910207-4}}</ref> The word condor itself is derived from the [[Quechua language|Quechua]] ''kuntur''.<ref>{{Cite encyclopedia| title=Raven|encyclopedia=Oxford English Dictionary|editor1=J. Simpson |editor2=E. Weiner | year=1989 |edition= 2nd| location=Oxford |publisher=Clarendon Press|isbn= 0-19-861186-2}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.quechua.org.uk/Eng/Main/AnalysisMainFrame.htm |title=A Quechua metaphor for a plane: Kuntur-man = "looking like a Condor" |publisher=Quechua.org.uk |accessdate=2010-03-20}}</ref>
The exact [[Taxonomy (biology)|taxonomic]] placement of the Andean condor and the remaining six species of [[New World vulture]]s remains unclear.<ref name="SACC"/> Although both are similar in appearance and have similar [[ecological niche|ecological roles]], the New World and [[Old World vultures]] evolved from different ancestors in different parts of the world and are not closely related. Just how different the two families are is currently under debate, with some earlier authorities suggesting that the New World vultures are more closely related to [[storks]].<ref name="SibleyMonroe">[[Charles Sibley|Sibley, Charles G.]] and Monroe, Burt L. (1990). ''[https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN0300049692 Distribution and Taxonomy of the Birds of the World]''. Yale University Press. {{ISBN|0-300-04969-2}}. Retrieved 2007-04-11.</ref> More recent authorities maintain their overall position in the order [[Falconiformes]] along with the Old World vultures<ref name=Sibley1991/> or place them in their own order, Cathartiformes.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1098/rsbl.2006.0523|title=Diversification of Neoaves: Integration of molecular sequence data and fossils|year=2006|last1=Ericson|first1=P. G.P|last2=Anderson|first2=C. L|last3=Britton|first3=T.|last4=Elzanowski|first4=A.|last5=Johansson|first5=U. S|last6=Kallersjo|first6=M.|last7=Ohlson|first7=J. I|last8=Parsons|first8=T. J|last9=Zuccon|first9=D.|displayauthors=8|journal=Biology Letters|volume=2|issue=4|pages=543–7|pmid=17148284|pmc=1834003}}</ref> The [[South American Classification Committee]] has removed the New World vultures from [[Ciconiiformes]] and instead described them as ''[[incertae sedis]]'', but notes that a move to Falconiformes or Cathartiformes is possible.<ref name="SACC">Remsen, J. V., Jr.; Cadena, C. D.; Jaramillo, A.; Nores, M.; Pacheco, J. F.; Robbins, M. B.; Schulenberg, T. S.; Stiles, F. G.; Stotz, D. F. and Zimmer, K. J. (2007). [http://www.museum.lsu.edu/~Remsen/SACCBaseline.html ''A classification of the bird species of South America.''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090302073659/http://www.museum.lsu.edu/~Remsen/SACCBaseline.html |date=2009-03-02 }} South American Classification Committee. Retrieved on 2007-10-15</ref>
The Andean condor is the only accepted living species of its [[genus]], ''Vultur''.<ref>{{cite web | title = ''Vultur gryphus'' | publisher = Integrated Taxonomic Information System | url = http://itis.gov/servlet/SingleRpt/SingleRpt?search_topic=TSN&search_value=175279 | accessdate = 2008-01-13}}</ref> Unlike the [[California condor]] (''Gymnogyps californianus''), which is known from extensive [[fossil]] remains and some additional ones of [[:wiktionary:congener|congeners]], the fossil record of the Andean condor recovered to date is scant. Presumed [[Plio-Pleistocene]] species of South American condors were later recognized to be not different from the present species, although one known only from a few rather small bones found in a Pliocene deposit of [[Tarija Department]], [[Bolivia]], may have been a smaller [[chronospecies|palaeosubspecies]], ''V. gryphus patruus''.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Fisher, Harvey L. |year=1944|title= The skulls of the Cathartid vultures|journal=[[Condor (journal)|Condor]]|volume=46|issue=6|pages= 272–296|url=http://sora.unm.edu/sites/default/files/journals/condor/v046n06/p0272-p0296.pdf| doi = 10.2307/1364013| jstor = 1364013}}</ref>
==Description== [[File:Vultur gryphus head (Linnaeus, 1758).jpg|right|thumb|There is a dark red caruncle (or comb) on the top of the head of the adult male.]]
[[File:Vultur gryphus -Franklin Park Zoo, Massachusetts, USA -female-8a (1).jpg|right|thumb|Adult female at [[Franklin Park Zoo]], USA]] [[File:Vultur gryphus talon.jpg|thumb|right|Detail of talon showing elongated middle toe]] Although it is on average about seven to eight cm shorter from beak to tail than the [[California condor]], the Andean condor is larger in wingspan, which ranges from {{convert|270|to|320|cm|ftin|0|abbr=on}}.<ref name="Ferguson-Lees"/> It is also typically heavier, reaching a weight of {{convert|11|to|15|kg|lb|abbr=on}} for males and {{convert|8|to|11|kg|lb|abbr=on}} for females.<ref name="Handbookof">{{cite book |title=[[Handbook of the Birds of the World]] |last1=del Hoyo |first1=J | last2=Elliot | first2 = A | last3=Sargatal | first3 = J | year=1996 |publisher=[[Lynx Edicions]] |location=[[Barcelona]] |isbn=84-87334-20-2|volume=3}}</ref> Overall length can range from {{convert|100|to|130|cm|ftin|abbr=on}}.<ref name="Handbookof" /> Among standard measurements, the [[Wing chord (biology)|wing chord]] is {{convert|75.7|-|85.2|cm|in|abbr=on}}, the [[tail]] is {{convert|33|-|38|cm|in|abbr=on}} and the [[Tarsus (skeleton)|tarsus]] is {{convert|11.5|-|12.5|cm|in|abbr=on}}.<ref name="Ferguson-Lees"/> Measurements are usually taken from specimens reared in captivity.<ref name="Ferguson-Lees"/> The mean weight is {{convert|11.3|kg|lb|abbr=on}}, with the males averaging about a kilogram more at {{convert|12.5|kg|lb|abbr=on}}, the females a kilogram less at {{convert|10.1|kg|lb|abbr=on}}. According to a recently published manual of avian body masses, the species possesses the heaviest average weight for any living flying bird or animal, ahead of competitors such as [[trumpeter swan]]s (''Cygnus buccinator'') and [[Dalmatian pelican]]s (''Pelecanus crispus'').<ref name = "CRC">''CRC Handbook of Avian Body Masses, 2nd Edition'' by John B. Dunning Jr. (Editor). CRC Press (2008), {{ISBN|978-1-4200-6444-5}}.</ref><ref>Wallace, M. P., & Temple, S. A. (1987). ''Competitive interactions within and between species in a guild of avian scavengers''. The Auk, 290-295.</ref> However, another resources claims a mean species body mass of {{convert|10.3|kg|lb|abbr=on}} for the Andean condor.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Atanasov | first1 = A. T. | year = 2007 | title = The near to linear allometric relationship between total metabolic energy per life span and body mass of nonpasserine birds | url = | journal = Bulgarian Journal of Veterinary Medicine | volume = 10 | issue = 4| pages = 235–245 }}</ref> The Andean condor is the largest living land bird capable of flight if measured in terms of average weight and wingspan, although male [[bustard]]s of the largest species (far more sexually dimorphic in size) can weigh more at maximum.<ref name="Handbookof" /><ref>[http://www.birdlife.org/datazone/speciesfactsheet.php?id=3822 Andean Condor ''Vultur gryphus'']. Birdlife International.</ref><ref name="Wood">{{cite book | author = Wood, Gerald| title =The Guinness Book of Animal Facts and Feats| year = 1983 | isbn = 978-0-85112-235-9}}</ref> The mean wingspan is around {{convert|283|cm|ftin|0|abbr=on}} and the wings have the largest surface area (measured in square centimeters) of any extant bird.<ref name="Wood"/> Among living bird species, only the [[great albatross]]es and the two largest species of [[pelican]] exceed the Andean condor in average and maximal wingspan.<ref name="Wood"/><ref name="Harrison">Harrison, Peter, ''Seabirds: An Identification Guide''. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt (1991), {{ISBN|978-0-395-60291-1}}</ref>
The adult [[plumage]] is a uniform black, with the exception of a frill of white feathers nearly surrounding the base of the neck and, especially in the male, large patches or bands of white on the wings which do not appear until the completion of the bird's first [[moult]]ing.<ref name="Hilty">{{cite book | last =Hilty | first =Stephen L. | title =A Guide to the Birds of Colombia | publisher =Princeton University Press | year =1977 | page =88 | url =https://books.google.com/?id=1k5fV_hQqE8C&pg=PA88 | isbn =0-691-08372-X }}</ref> The head and neck are red to blackish-red and have few feathers. The head and neck are meticulously kept clean by the bird,<ref name=CleMet3>{{cite web |title=Behavior of the Andean Condor |publisher=Cleveland Metroparks Zoo |url=http://www.clemetzoo.com/rttw/condor/behavior.htm |accessdate=2007-01-10 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061219194934/http://www.clemetzoo.com/rttw/condor/behavior.htm |archivedate=19 December 2006 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> and their baldness is an adaptation for hygiene, allowing the skin to be exposed to the [[Sterilization (microbiology)|sterilizing]] effects of [[dehydration]] and [[ultraviolet light]] at high altitudes.<ref name="Patagonia">{{cite book | last = Lutz | first = Dick|author2=Lutz, Richard L.| title = Patagonia: At the Bottom of the World | publisher = DIMI Press | year = 2002| pages = 71–74|url=https://books.google.com/?id=0CZTQn15YhUC&pg=PA73 | isbn = 0-931625-38-6}}</ref> The crown of the head is flattened. In the male, the head is crowned with a dark red caruncle or comb, while the skin of his neck lies in folds, forming a wattle.<ref name="Hilty"/> The skin of the head and neck is capable of flushing noticeably in response to emotional state, which serves to communicate between individuals. Juveniles have a grayish-brown general coloration, blackish head and neck skin, and a brown ruff. <ref name="Blake">{{cite book | author = Blake, Emmet Reid | title =Birds of Mexico: A Guide for Field Identification | publisher =University of Chicago Press | year =1953 | pages =262–263 | url =https://books.google.com/?id=YP0AX3LW8jYC | isbn= 0-226-05641-4}}</ref>
The middle toe is greatly elongated, and the hind one is only slightly developed, while the talons of all the toes are comparatively straight and blunt. The feet are thus more adapted to walking, and are of little use as weapons or organs of [[prehension]] as in birds of prey and [[Old World vulture]]s.<ref name="Feduccia"/> The beak is hooked, and adapted to tear rotting meat.<ref name="SanDiego"/> The [[iris (anatomy)|irises]] of the male are brown, while those of the female are deep red.<ref name="Smithsonian"/> The eyelids lack eyelashes.<ref name=" Pterylosis ">{{Cite journal| last = Fisher| first = Harvey L.| title = The Pterylosis of the Andean Condor|url=http://sora.unm.edu/node/99237 | journal = [[Condor (journal)|Condor]]| volume = 44 | issue = 1| pages = 30–32| year = 1942| doi = 10.2307/1364195| jstor =1364195 }}</ref> Contrary to the usual rule for [[sexual dimorphism]] among [[bird of prey|birds of prey]],<ref>{{cite book |last = Andersson |first = Malte B. |title = Sexual selection |publisher = Princeton University Press |year = 1994 |page = 269 |accessdate = 19 July 2010 |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=lNnHdvzBlTYC |isbn = 978-0-691-00057-2}}</ref> the female is smaller than the male.<ref>{{cite book |last1 = Arnold |first1 = Caroline |last2 = Wallace |first2 = Michael Phillip |last3 = Wallace |first3 = Michael |title = On the brink of extinction: the California condor |publisher = Houghton Mifflin Harcourt |year = 1993 |page = 11 |accessdate = 19 July 2010 |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=dQYHp0csAvcC |isbn = 978-0-15-257990-6}}</ref>
==Distribution and habitat== [[File:Condor des Andes mâle adulte.jpg|thumb|right| Andean condor, in Chilean national park [[Torres del Paine]]]] The Andean condor is found in [[South America]] in the [[Andes]], including the [[Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta|Santa Marta Mountains]]. In the north, its range begins in [[Venezuela]] and [[Colombia]], where it is extremely rare,<ref name="BirdLife"/> then continues south along the Andes in [[Ecuador]], [[Peru]], and [[Chile]], through [[Bolivia]] and western [[Argentina]] to the [[Tierra del Fuego]].<ref name="Blake"/> In the early 19th century, the Andean condor bred from western Venezuela to Tierra del Fuego, along the entire chain of the Andes, but its range has been greatly reduced due to human activity.<ref name="Haemig "/> Its habitat is mainly composed of open grasslands and alpine areas up to {{convert|5000|m|ft|abbr=on}} in elevation. It prefers relatively open, non-forested areas which allow it to spot carrion from the air, such as the [[páramo]] or rocky, mountainous areas in general.<ref>{{cite web |title=Habitat of the Andean Condor |publisher=Cleveland Metroparks Zoo |url=http://www.clemetzoo.com/rttw/condor/habitat.htm |accessdate=2007-01-10 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061220141630/http://www.clemetzoo.com/rttw/condor/habitat.htm |archivedate=20 December 2006 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> It occasionally ranges to lowlands in eastern Bolivia and southwestern Brazil,<ref name="SibleyMonroe"/> descends to lowland desert areas in Chile and Peru, and is found over [[Nothofagus|southern-beech]] forests in [[Patagonia]].<ref name="BirdLife"/>
==Ecology and behavior== [[File:Andean Condor in flight.jpg|thumb|left|Soaring over [[Arequipa]] in southern [[Peru]]]] The condor soars with its wings held horizontally and its [[primary feather]]s bent upwards at the tips.<ref name="Hilty"/> The lack of a large [[sternum]] to anchor its correspondingly large flight muscles physiologically identifies it as primarily being a soarer. It flaps its wings on rising from the ground, but after attaining a moderate elevation it flaps its wings very rarely, relying on thermals to stay aloft.<ref name="Wehner"/> [[Charles Darwin]] commented on having watched them for half an hour without once observing a flap of their wings.<ref>{{cite book | last =Darwin | first= Charles | title =The Voyage of the Beagle | publisher =P.F. Collier | year =1909 | page=201 | url= https://books.google.com/?id=tbIvCXHcXLAC&printsec=frontcover}}</ref> It prefers to roost on high places from which it can launch without major wing-flapping effort. Andean condors are often seen soaring near rock cliffs, using the heat [[thermals]] to aid them in rising in the air.<ref name="Benson">{{cite book |author1=Benson, Sara |author2=Paul Hellander | title =Peru | publisher =Lonely Planet Publications | year =2007 | page=53 | url= https://books.google.com/?id=4OOKiVflYFQC | isbn = 1-74059-749-4}}</ref>
Like other [[New World vulture]]s, the Andean condor has the unusual habit of [[urohidrosis]]: it often empties its [[cloaca]] onto its legs and feet. A cooling effect through [[evaporative cooling|evaporation]] has been proposed as a reason for this behavior, but it does not make any sense in the cold Andean habitat of the bird.<ref name=Sibley1991>{{cite book |author1=Sibley, Charles G. |author2=Jon E. Ahlquist | title =Phylogeny and Classification of Birds: A Study in Molecular Evolution | publisher =Yale University Press | year =1991 | url= https://books.google.com/books?visbn=0300040857 | isbn = 0-300-04085-7}}</ref> Because of this habit, their legs are often streaked with a white buildup of [[uric acid]].<ref name="Feduccia">{{cite book | last =Feduccia | first =J. Alan | title =The Origin and Evolution of Birds | publisher =Yale University Press | year =1999 | page =300 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=8QRKV7eSqmIC&pg=PA300 | isbn =0-226-05641-4 }}</ref>
There is a well-developed social structure within large groups of condors, with competition to determine a 'pecking order' by body language, competitive play behavior, and [[Bird vocalization|vocalizations]].<ref>{{cite journal | last = Donazard | first = José A | author2 = Feijoo, Juan E. | title = Social structure of Andean Condor roosts: Influence of sex, age, and season | journal =[[Condor (journal)|Condor]] | volume = 104 | issue = 1 | pages = 832–837 | publisher =Cooper Ornithological Society | url = http://cat.inist.fr/?aModele=afficheN&cpsidt=14022914 | accessdate =2008-01-10 | doi = 10.1650/0010-5422(2002)104[0832:SSOACR]2.0.CO;2 | year = 2002 | issn = 0010-5422 }}</ref> Generally, mature males tend to be at the top of the pecking order, with post-dispersal immature males tending to be near the bottom.<ref name="Ferguson-Lees"/>
===Breeding=== [[File:Vultur gryphus MWNH 0718.JPG|left|thumb|Egg, Collection [[Museum Wiesbaden]]]] [[File:Condor02 ST 98.jpg|thumb|right|A juvenile condor in [[Colca Canyon]], [[Peru]].]] [[File:Condor des andes immature.jpg|thumb|right|A young female Andean condor, in [[Nahuel Huapi National Park]], [[Argentina]].]]
Sexual maturity and breeding behavior do not appear in the Andean condor until the bird is five or six years of age.<ref>{{cite web |title=Andean Condor (''Vultur Gryphus'') |publisher=[[The Peregrine Fund]] |url=http://www.peregrinefund.org/explore_raptors/vultures/andcondr.html |accessdate=2007-01-10 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070205055624/http://www.peregrinefund.org/Explore_Raptors/vultures/andcondr.html |archivedate=5 February 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> It may live to 50 years or more, and it mates for life.<ref name="Tait"/> During courtship displays, the skin of the male's neck flushes, changing from dull red to bright yellow, and inflates.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Whitson | first = Martha A | author2 = Whitson, Paul D. | title = Breeding Behavior of the Andean Condor (''Vultur Gryphus'') | journal =[[Condor (journal)|Condor]] | volume = 71 | pages = 73–75 | publisher =Cooper Ornithological Society | year =1968 | url =http://sora.unm.edu/sites/default/files/journals/condor/v071n01/p0073-p0075.pdf | accessdate = 2007-01-10 | doi = 10.2307/1366056 |format=PDF | jstor = 1366056 | issue = 1}}</ref> He approaches the female with neck outstretched, revealing the inflated neck and the chest patch, while hissing,<ref>{{cite journal | last = Gailey | first = Janet | author2 = Bolwig, Neils | title =Observations on the Breeding Behavior of the Andean Condor (''Vultur Gryphus'') | journal =[[Condor (journal)|Condor]] | publisher =Cooper Ornithological Society | volume = 75 | pages = 60–68 | year =1973 | url =http://sora.unm.edu/sites/default/files/journals/condor/v075n01/p0060-p0068.pdf | accessdate = 2007-01-10 | doi =10.2307/1366535 |format=PDF | jstor = 1366535 | issue = 1}}</ref> then extends his wings and stands erect while clicking his tongue.<ref name="Smithsonian"/> Other courtship rituals include hissing and clucking while hopping with wings partially spread, and dancing.<ref name="Patagonia"/> The Andean condor prefers to roost and breed at elevations of {{convert|3000|to|5000|m|ft|abbr=on}}.<ref name="Fjeldså">{{cite book | last = Fjeldså | first =Jon | author2= Krabbe, Niels | title =Birds of the High Andes | publisher =Apollo Books | year =1990 | page =90 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=NmXSeVrmlgIC | isbn =87-88757-16-1 }}</ref> Its nest, which consists of a few sticks placed around the eggs, is created on inaccessible ledges of rock. However, in coastal areas of Peru, where there are few cliffs, some nests are simply partially shaded crannies scraped out against boulders on slopes.<ref name="Haemig "/> It deposits one or two bluish-white [[egg (biology)|eggs]], weighing about {{convert|280|g|oz|abbr=on}} and ranging from {{convert|75|to|100|mm|in|abbr=on}} in length, during the months of February and March every second year. The egg hatches after 54 to 58 days of [[Avian incubation|incubation]] by both parents.<ref name="Smithsonian">{{cite web |author=Friends of the Zoo |title=Andean Condor |publisher=Smithsonian National Zoological Park |url=http://nationalzoo.si.edu/Animals/Birds/Facts/FactSheets/fact-andeancondor.cfm |accessdate=2008-01-08 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071009075845/http://nationalzoo.si.edu/Animals/Birds/Facts/FactSheets/fact-andeancondor.cfm |archivedate=2007-10-09 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> If the chick or egg is lost or removed, another egg is laid to take its place. Researchers and breeders take advantage of this behavior to double the reproductive rate by taking the first egg away for hand-rearing, causing the parents to lay a second egg, which they are generally allowed to raise.<ref> {{cite book | author=National Research Council | title = Scientific Bases for the Preservation of the Hawaiian Crow | publisher =National Academies Press | year = 1992 | page =74 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=8cDX2mb07mcC&pg=PA74 | isbn =0-309-04775-7 }}</ref>
The young are covered with a grayish down until they are almost as large as their parents. They are able to fly after six months,<ref name="Hilty"/> but continue to roost and hunt with their parents until age two, when they are displaced by a new clutch.<ref>Cisneros-Heredia, Diego F. (2006). [http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.177.5617&rep=rep1&type=pdf "Notes on breeding, behaviour and distribution of some birds in Ecuador"]. ''Bulletin of the British Ornithologists' Club'' '''126''' (2): 153–164 contains a record of a juvenile accompanying an adult male in July, too early to have been of that year's cohort.</ref> Healthy adults have no natural predators, but large [[birds of prey]] and [[mammal]]ian predators, like [[fox]]es, may take eggs or hatchlings. Predation is relatively uncommon, since the vigilant parents often aggressively displace birds of prey who come near and the rocky, precipitous location of most nests are difficult for mammals to access.
===Feeding=== The Andean condor is a [[scavenger]], feeding mainly on [[carrion]].<ref name="Wehner">{{cite book | last =Wehner | first =Ross | author2= del Gaudio, Renee |author3=Jankowski, Kazia | title =Moon Peru | publisher =Avalon Travel | year =2007 | page =180 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=2tVNa8P0inYC&pg=PA180 | isbn =1-56691-983-5 }}</ref> Wild condors inhabit large territories, often traveling more than {{convert|200|km|mi|abbr=on}} a day in search of carrion.<ref name="Patagonia"/> In inland areas, they prefer large carcasses. Naturally, they feed on the largest carcasses available, which can include [[llama]]s (''Lama glama''), [[alpaca]]s (''Vicugna pacos''), [[rhea (bird)|rhea]]s (''Rhea ssp.''), [[guanaco]]s (''Lama guanicoe''), [[deer]] and [[armadillo]]s. Wild individuals could acquire extra carotenoids from vegetal matter contained in carcass viscera and fresh vegetation.<ref name="Blanco2013">{{cite journal | last1=Blanco |first1=G. |last2=Hornero-Méndez |first2=D. |last3=Lambertucci |first3=S.A. |last4=Donázar |first4=J.A. |last5=Bautista |first5=L.M. |last6= Wiemeyer |first6=G. |last7=Sanchez-Zapata |first7=J.A. |last8=Garrido-Fernández |first8=J. |last9=Hiraldo |first9=F. |year=2013 |title=Need and seek for dietary micronutrients: endogenous regulation, external signaling and food sources of carotenoids in New World vultures |journal=PLoS ONE |volume=6 |page=e65562 |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0065562 |PMID=23785435 |url=https://digital.csic.es/handle/10261/78234?locale=en |pmc=3681859}}</ref> However, most inland condors now live largely off of domestic animals, which are now more widespread in South America, such as [[cattle]] (''Bos primigenius taurus''), [[horse]]s (''Equus ferus caballus''), [[donkey]]s (''Equus africanus a sinus''), [[mule]]s, [[sheep]] (''Ovis aries''), [[pig]]s (''Sus scrofa domesticus''), [[goat]]s (''Capra aegagrus hircus'') and [[dog]]s (''Canis lupus familiaris''). They also feed on the carcasses of introduced game species such as [[wild boar]]s (''Sus scrofa''), [[rabbit]]s (''Oryctolagus cuniculus''), [[fox]]es (''Vulpes vulpes'') and [[red deer]] (''Cervus elaphus''). For condors who live around the coast, the diet consists mainly of beached carcasses of marine mammals, largely [[cetacean]]s.<ref name="Smithsonian"/><ref name="ADW"/> They will also raid the nests of smaller birds to feed on the eggs.<ref>{{cite web | title =Andean Condor (''Vultur Gryphus'') | publisher = [[National Geographic Society|National Geographic]] | url = http://animals.nationalgeographic.com/animals/birds/andean-condor.html | accessdate = 2007-01-10}}</ref> Andean condors have been observed to do some hunting of small, live animals, such as [[rodent]]s, [[bird]]s and [[rabbit]]s, which (given their lack of powerful, grasping feet or developed hunting technique) they usually kill by jabbing repeatedly with their bill.<ref name= ADW>[http://animaldiversity.ummz.umich.edu/site/accounts/information/Vultur_gryphus.html ADW: Vultur gryphus: INFORMATION]. Animaldiversity.ummz.umich.edu. Retrieved on 2012-12-19.</ref>
Coastal areas provide a constant food supply, and in particularly plentiful areas, some Andean condors limit their foraging area to several kilometers of beach-front land.<ref name="Haemig ">{{cite web |last=Haemig |first=PD |title=Ecology of Condors |publisher=Ecology Online Sweden |year=2007 |url=http://www.ecology.info/condors.htm |accessdate=March 30, 2009 }}</ref> They locate carrion by spotting it or by following other scavengers, such as [[corvid]]s or other vultures.<ref name="snyder">{{cite book |author1=Snyder, Noel F. R. |author2=Helen Snyder | title =Raptors of North America: Natural History and Conservation | publisher =Voyageur Press | page=45 | year =2006 | url= https://books.google.com/?id=g6aOgkIbEwEC&pg=PA40 | isbn = 0-7603-2582-0}}</ref> It may follow New World vultures of the genus ''[[Cathartes]]''—the [[turkey vulture]] (''C. aura''), the [[lesser yellow-headed vulture]] (''C. burrovianus''), and the [[greater yellow-headed vulture]] (''C. melambrotus'')—to carcasses. The ''Cathartes'' vultures forage by smell, detecting the scent of [[Ethanethiol|ethyl mercaptan]], a gas produced by the beginnings of decay in dead animals. These smaller vultures cannot rip through the tougher hides of these larger animals with the efficiency of the larger condor, and their interactions are often an example of [[mutual dependence]] between species.<ref name="Dietland">{{cite book | last =Muller-Schwarze | first =Dietland | title =Chemical Ecology of Vertebrates | publisher =Cambridge University Press | page=350 | year =2006 | url= https://books.google.com/?id=HaaFlUw4goIC&pg=PA1 | isbn = 0-521-36377-2}}</ref> [[Black vulture]]s (''Coragyps atratus''), [[king vulture]]s (''Sarcoramphus papa'') and even mammalian scavengers may sometimes track ''Cathartes'' vultures for carcasses but the condor is invariably dominant among the scavengers in its range.<ref>[http://www.ecology.info/condors.htm Ecology of Condors: the California Condor and Andean Condor]. Ecology.info. Retrieved on 2012-12-19.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ecology.info/condors.htm |title=Ecology of Condors |accessdate=2006-10-05 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061001235133/http://www.ecology.info/condors.htm |archivedate=2006-10-01 |df= }}. ecology.info.</ref> Andean condors are intermittent eaters in the wild, often going for a few days without eating, then gorging themselves on several pounds at once, sometimes to the point of being unable to lift off the ground. Because its feet and talons are not adapted to grasping, it must feed while on the ground.<ref name="Patagonia"/> Like other carrion-feeders, it plays an important role in its [[ecosystem]] by disposing of carrion which would otherwise be a breeding ground for disease.<ref name="cotton">{{cite journal |last=Gomez |title=The role of greater yellow-headed vultures Cathartes melambrotus as scavengers in neotropical forest |journal=Ibis |volume=136 |issue=2 |pages=193–196 |year=1994 |url=http://md1.csa.com/partners/viewrecord.php?requester=gs&collection=ENV&recid=3646491&q=Cathartes+melambrotus&uid=791396595&setcookie=yes |accessdate=2008-01-06 |doi=10.1111/j.1474-919X.1994.tb01084.x |first1=Luis G. |last2=Houston |first2=David C. |last3=Cotton |first3=Peter |last4=Tye |first4=Alan |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080129233040/http://md1.csa.com/partners/viewrecord.php?requester=gs&collection=ENV&recid=3646491&q=Cathartes+melambrotus&uid=791396595&setcookie=yes |archivedate=29 January 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
===Longevity=== Being a slowly-maturing bird with no known natural predators in adulthood, an Andean condor is a long-lived bird. Longevity and mortality rates are not known to have been extensively studied in the wild. Some estimations of lifespans of wild birds has exceeded 50 years. In 1983, the [[Guinness Book of World Records]] considered the longest-lived bird of any species with a confirmed lifespan was an Andean condor that died after surviving 72 years in captivity, having been captured from the wild as a juvenile of undetermined age.<ref name="Wood"/> Several species of [[parrot]] have been reported to live for perhaps over 100 years, but these (at least in 1983) were not considered authenticated.<ref name="Wood"/> Another early captive-held specimen of condor reportedly lived for 71 years.<ref name="Wood"/> However, these lifespans have been exceeded by a male, nicknamed "Thaao", that was kept [[Beardsley Zoo]] in [[Connecticut]]. Thaao was born in captivity in 1930 and died on January 26, 2010, making him 79 years of age.<ref>[http://beardsleyzoo.org/node/150 Zoo Family Mourns Death of Oldest Living Andean Condor in Captivity | Connecticut's Beardsley Zoo] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120520105325/http://www.beardsleyzoo.org/node/150 |date=2012-05-20 }}. Beardsleyzoo.org (2010-01-26). Retrieved on 2012-12-19.</ref> This would be the greatest verified age ever known for a bird.<ref name="Wood"/>
==Relationship with humans==
===Conservation status=== [[File:Vultur gryphus -Taronga Zoo, Australia-8a.jpg|thumb|right|Adult male at [[Taronga Zoo]], Australia]] The Andean condor is considered [[Near Threatened|near threatened]] by the [[IUCN]].<ref name=IUCN/> It was first placed on the United States [[Endangered Species]] list in 1970,<ref>{{cite web|title=Species Profile: Andean Condor |publisher=United States Department of Fish and Wildlife |url=http://ecos.fws.gov/speciesProfile/SpeciesReport.do?spcode=B03Y |accessdate=2007-10-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090303165337/http://ecos.fws.gov/speciesProfile/SpeciesReport.do?spcode=B03Y |archivedate=March 3, 2009 }}</ref> a status which is assigned to an animal that is in danger of extinction throughout all or a significant portion of its range.<ref>{{cite web |title=Endangered Species Program |publisher=United States Department of Fish and Wildlife |url=http://www.fws.gov/Endangered/wildlife.html |accessdate=2007-10-16 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070921072436/http://www.fws.gov/Endangered/wildlife.html |archivedate=2007-09-21 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Threats to its population include loss of habitat needed for foraging, secondary poisoning from animals killed by hunters and persecution.<ref name="Reading">{{cite book | last =Reading | first =Richard P. | author2 =Miller, Brian | title =Endangered Animals: A Reference Guide to Conflicting Issues | publisher =Greenwood Press | year =2000 | page =16 | url =https://books.google.com/?id=f_AWCtX29-kC&pg=PA16 | isbn = 0-313-30816-0}}</ref> It is threatened mainly in the northern area of its range, and is extremely rare in [[Venezuela]] and [[Colombia]], where it has undergone considerable declines in recent years.<ref>{{cite book | last =Beletsky | first =Les | title =Birds of the World | publisher =JHU Press | year =2006 | page =70 | url =https://books.google.com/?id=50_95BRVIjkC | isbn =0-8018-8429-2 }}</ref> Because it is adapted to very low mortality and has correspondingly low reproductive rates, it is extremely vulnerable to human persecution,<ref name="BirdLife">{{cite web|title=Species factsheet: Vultur Gryphus |year=2004 |publisher=BirdLife International |url=http://www.redlist.org/search/details.php?species=40258 |accessdate=2008-01-04 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060305172904/http://www.redlist.org/search/details.php?species=40258 |archivedate=2006-03-05 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> most of which stems from the fact that it is perceived as a threat by farmers due to alleged attacks on livestock.<ref name="Tait">{{cite book | last =Tait | first =Malcolm | title =Going, Going, Gone: Animals and Plants on the Brink of Extinction | publisher =Sterling Publishing | year =2006 | page =22 | url =https://books.google.com/?id=q6YCZynPvqsC&pg=RA1-PA22 | isbn = 1-84525-027-3}}</ref> Education programs have been implemented by conservationists to dispel this misconception.<ref name="Roach"/> Reintroduction programs using captive-bred Andean condors, which release birds hatched in North American zoos into the wild to bolster populations,<ref name="Roach">{{cite web | last =Roach | first =John | title =Peru's Andean Condors Are Rising Tourist Attraction | work = National Geographic News | publisher = [[National Geographic Society|National Geographic]] | date = 2004-07-22 | url = http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2004/07/0722_040722_andeancondor.html | accessdate = 2007-01-10}}</ref> have been introduced in [[Argentina]], Venezuela, and Colombia. The first captive-bred Andean condors were released into the wild in 1989.<ref>{{cite web |author=Conservation and Research for Endangered Species |title=Andean Condor Reintroduction Program |publisher=Zoological Society of San Diego |url=http://cres.sandiegozoo.org/projects/rb_condor_andean.html |accessdate=2007-01-10 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061010112901/http://cres.sandiegozoo.org/projects/rb_condor_andean.html |archivedate=2006-10-10 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> When raising condors, human contact is minimal; chicks are fed with glove puppets which resemble adult Andean condors in order to prevent the chicks from [[imprinting (psychology)|imprinting]] on humans, which would endanger them upon release as they would not be wary of humans.<ref name="Pullin"/> The condors are kept in aviaries for three months prior to release, where they acclimatize to an environment similar to that which they will be released in.<ref name="Pullin">{{cite book | last = Pullin | first = Andrew S. | title = Conservation Biology | publisher = Cambridge University Press | year = 2002 | page = 234 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=ED-8V8cE67UC&pg=PA234 | isbn = 0-521-64482-8}}</ref> Released condors are tracked by satellite in order to observe their movements and to monitor whether they are still alive.<ref name="SanDiego"/>
In response to the capture of all the wild individuals of the [[California condor]], in 1988 the [[US Fish and Wildlife Service]] began a reintroduction experiment involving the release of captive Andean condors into the wild in [[California]]. Only females were released to prevent it becoming an [[invasive species]]. The experiment was a success, and all the Andean condors were recaptured and re-released in South America before the reintroduction of the California condors took place.<ref name="USFW">{{cite web | title = California condor, (Gymnogyps californianus) | publisher= U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service| url = http://www.fws.gov/species/species_accounts/bio_cond.html| accessdate = 2007-08-14}}</ref>
In June 2014, local authorities of the [[Ancasmarca]] region rescued two Andean condors that were caged and displayed in a local market as an attraction for tourists.<ref>{{es}} [http://www.andina.com.pe/agencia/noticia-rescatan-dos-condores-andinos-eran-exhibidos-a-turistas-calca-cusco-509987.aspx Rescatan dos cóndores andinos que eran exhibidos a turistas en Calca Cusco], ''Andina.com.pe'', 12 June 2014</ref>
===Role in culture=== [[File:Chancay Sleeved Tunic with Flying Condors.png|thumb|[[Chancay culture|Chancay]] textile with flying condors, 1200-1400 AD]] The Andean condor is a national symbol of [[Argentina]], [[Bolivia]], [[Chile]], [[Colombia]], [[Ecuador]], [[Peru]] and [[Andean Region, Venezuela|Venezuelan Andes]] states. It is the [[List of national birds|national bird]] of Bolivia, Chile, Colombia, and Ecuador.<ref>{{cite web | last =MacDonald | first =Tina | author2 = MacDonald, Duncan | title =National Birds | url =http://www.camacdonald.com/birding/CountryIndex.htm | accessdate = 2007-10-06 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071006063912/http://www.camacdonald.com/birding/CountryIndex.htm#A| archivedate= 6 October 2007 | deadurl= no}}</ref> It plays an important role in the [[folklore]] and [[mythology]] of the [[South American]] Andean regions,<ref name="Tait"/> and has been represented in Andean art from c. 2500 BCE onward,<ref name="Werness">{{cite book | last =Werness | first =Hope B. | title =The Continuum Encyclopedia of Animal Symbolism in Art | publisher =Continuum International Publishing Group | year =2004 | page =103 | url =https://books.google.com/?id=fr2rANLrPmoC | isbn =0-8264-1525-3 }}</ref> and they are a part of indigenous Andean religions.<ref name="Howard-Malverde">{{cite book | last =Howard-Malverde | first =Rosaleen | title =Creating Context in Andean Cultures | publisher =Oxford University Press | year =1997 | page =16 | url =https://books.google.com/?id=t7ybxALxNfwC&pg=PA16 | isbn =0-19-510914-7 }}</ref> In Andean mythology, the Andean condor was associated with the sun deity,<ref>{{cite book | last = Mundkur | first =Balaji | title =The Cult of the Serpent | publisher =SUNY Press | year =1983 | page =129 | url =https://books.google.com/?id=PDkuiPhZJr0C | isbn =0-87395-631-1 }}</ref> and was believed to be the ruler of the upper world.<ref>{{cite book |author1=Mills, Alice |author2=Parker, Janet |author3=Stanton, Julie | title =Mythology: Myths, Legends and Fantasies | publisher =New Holland Publishers | year =2006 | page =493 | isbn =1-77007-453-8}}</ref> The Andean condor is considered a symbol of power and health by many Andean cultures, and it was believed that the bones and organs of the Andean condor possessed medicinal powers, sometimes leading to the hunting and killing of condors to obtain its bones and organs.<ref name="SanDiego">{{cite web | title = Andean Condor | publisher = Zoological Society of San Diego | url = http://www.sandiegozoo.org/animalbytes/t-andean_condor.html | accessdate = 2007-01-10}}</ref><ref name="CleMet2">{{cite web |title=History of the Andean Condor |publisher=Cleveland Metroparks Zoo |url=http://www.clemetzoo.com/rttw/condor/history.htm |accessdate=2007-01-10 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061219195345/http://www.clemetzoo.com/rttw/condor/history.htm |archivedate=19 December 2006 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In some versions of Peruvian bullfighting, a condor is tied to the back of a bull, where it pecks at the animal as bullfighters fight it. The condor generally survives and is set free.<ref>{{cite book| last =Kokotovic| first =Misha| title = The Colonial Divide in Peruvian Narrative:Social Conflict and Transculturation | publisher = Sussex Academic Press| year = 2007| page =49| isbn =1-84519-184-6 }}</ref>
In Peru, they are occasionally shot, but more often revered and used for ceremonial purposes. The Yawar Fiesta is a celebration, the pinnacle of which is the tying of an Andean condor to the back of a bull, allowing the condor to kill the bull with its talons before being released. This ceremony is a symbolic representation of the power of the Andean peoples (the condor) over the Spanish (the bull).<ref>{{cite book| last =Arguedas| first =José María| title = Yawar Fiesta,| translator = Frances Horning Barraclough| publisher = NorthWood, Inc.| year = 2002| isbn =1-55971-019-5 }}</ref> There is also a ceremony known as the ''arranque del condor'' in which a live Andean condor is suspended from a frame and is punched to death by horsemen as they ride by.<ref>{{cite book| last =Mackenzie| first =John P.S.| title = Birds of Prey| publisher = Waveland Pr Inc.| year = 2002| location = Toronto| page =30| isbn =1-57766-245-8 }}</ref>
[[Condorito]] is a Chilean comic book and comic strip that features an anthropomorphic condor living in a fictitious town named Pelotillehue, a typical small Chilean provincial town. He is meant to be a representation of the Chilean people.
The Andean condor is a popular figure on [[postage stamp|stamps]] in many countries, appearing on one for [[Ecuador]] in 1958, [[Argentina]] in 1960, [[Peru]] in 1973, [[Bolivia]] in 1985, [[Colombia]] in 1992, [[Chile]] in 2001, and [[Venezuela]] in 2004.<ref name="Stamp ">{{cite web | title =Andean Condor | publisher =Bird Stamps | url = http://www.bird-stamps.org/cspecies/2800600.htm | accessdate = 2008-01-15}}</ref> It has also appeared on the coins and banknotes of Colombia and Chile.<ref>{{cite web | title =A Field Guide to the Birds on Banknotes | publisher =Krause Publications | url = http://members.tripod.com/~fieldguide/bobn.html | accessdate = 2008-01-16}}</ref> The condor is featured in several [[coat of arms|coats of arms]] of Andean countries as a symbol of [[Andes mountains]].
The Andean condor is depicted on the logo of [[Avianca]] and [[Aerolineas Argentinas]], which are two of the largest airlines in South America. <gallery> File:Escudo de la República Peruana (1821-1825).png|First [[Coat of arms of Peru|Coat of arms]] of [[Peru]]. File:Coat of arms of Bolivia.svg|[[Coat of arms of Bolivia|Coat of arms]] of [[Bolivia]] File:Coat of arms of Chile.svg|[[Coat of arms of Chile|Coat of arms]] of [[Chile]] File:Coat of arms of Colombia.svg|[[Coat of arms of Colombia|Coat of arms]] of [[Colombia]] File:Coat of arms of Ecuador.svg|[[Coat of arms of Ecuador|Coat of arms]] of [[Ecuador]] File:Coat_of_arms_of_Venezuela_(1812).svg|[[Coat of arms of Venezuela|Former coat of arms]] of [[Venezuela]] File:Escudo-UNAM-escalable.svg|Coat of arms of [[UNAM]] depicting a condor and [[golden eagle]] File:Vultur gryphus Chili XIX.jpg|Hunting for condor. Chile, 19th century.<ref>[http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.wdl/clsabn.3979 Atlas de la historia fisica y politica de Chile]. [Laminas, Volumen 1]. 1854.</ref> File:CondorLassoLyd.jpg|[[Gaucho]]s lassoing a condor<br />(illustration 1895) File:60 cent Chile Condor.jpg|Stamp of Chile, 60 centavos, 1935 </gallery>

{{Infobox NFL player |name=Andre Gurode |image=Andre Gurode.JPG |image_size=250px |alt= |caption=Gurode with the Cowboys in 2009 |current_team = |number=65, 64 |position=[[Center (American football)|Center]] / [[Guard (American football)|Guard]] |birth_date={{Birth date and age|1978|3|6|mf=y}} |birth_place=[[Houston, Texas]] |death_date= |death_place= |height_ft = 6 |height_in = 4 |weight_lbs = 320 |high_school = [[North Shore Senior High School (Texas)|North Shore]] ([[Houston, Texas]]) |college=[[Colorado Buffaloes football|Colorado]] |draftyear=2002 |draftround=2 |draftpick=37 |pastteams= * [[Dallas Cowboys]] ({{NFL Year|2002}}–{{NFL Year|2010}}) * [[Baltimore Ravens]] ({{NFL Year|2011}}) * [[Chicago Bears]] ({{NFL Year|2012}}) * [[Oakland Raiders]] ({{NFL Year|2013}}) |highlights= ;NFL * 5× [[Pro Bowl]] ([[2007 Pro Bowl|2006]]–[[2011 Pro Bowl|2010]]) * Second-team [[All-Pro]] ([[2009 All-Pro Team|2009]]) * [[Sporting News|SN]] [[All-Pro]] ([[2007 All-Pro Team|2007]]) ;College * Consensus [[All-American]] ([[2001 College Football All-America Team|2001]]) * 2× First-team All-[[Big 12 Conference|Big 12]] (2000, 2001) |statweek= |statseason= |statlabel1=Games played |statvalue1=161 |statlabel2=Games started |statvalue2=131 |nfl=GUR332232 |pfr=GuroAn20 }}
'''Andre Bernard Gurode''' ({{IPAc-en|dʒ|ə|ˈ|r|ɒ|d}}; born March 6, 1978) is a former [[American football]] [[Center (American football)|center]] and [[Guard (American football)|guard]] who played 11 seasons in the NFL. He played [[college football]] for the [[University of Colorado at Boulder|University of Colorado]], earning consensus [[All-America]]n recognition. The [[Dallas Cowboys]] selected him in the second round of the [[2002 NFL Draft]]. He is a five-time [[Pro Bowl]] selection, and has also played for the [[Baltimore Ravens]], [[Chicago Bears]], and [[Oakland Raiders]].
==Early years== Gurode was born in [[Houston, Texas]].<ref name=ProFootballReference.com>{{cite web|title=Gurode on Pro-Football-Reference |work=fbref.com |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/G/GuroAn20.htm|accessdate=2007-12-19| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071229021430/http://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/G/GuroAn20.htm| archivedate= 29 December 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> He played [[high school football]] at [[North Shore Senior High School (Texas)|North Shore High School]] in Houston. As a senior, ''[[USA Today]]'', [[PrepStar]] and SuperPrep selected him as an honorable mention high school [[All-America]]. He was also named to the '' [[Houston Chronicle]]'' Top 100 List and made the [[Austin American-Statesman]] "Fab 55" team. He earned All-Area honors as a senior (second team honors as a junior), and was All-District and All-Greater Houston as a junior and senior (when he also was his team's most outstanding offensive lineman).
Gurode lettered three times in [[basketball]] and four times in [[Track and field athletics|track]] with personal bests of 186' 0" in the [[Discus throw|discus]] and 54' 1" in the [[shot put]].
==College career== Gurode attended the [[University of Colorado]], where he played for the [[Colorado Buffaloes football]] team from 1998 to 2001. He was a four-year starter for the Buffaloes, playing both [[center (American football)|center]] and [[guard (American football)|guard]] on the [[offensive line]]. He started his first two and a half seasons at center, before moving to guard in the middle of his junior year. As a junior in 2000, he started the first six games of the year at center and the final five games at guard. He received the John Mack Award, as selected by the coaches for being Colorado's most outstanding offensive player and was also selected honorable mention All-[[Big 12 Conference]] honors while helping the Buffaloes to a 7–5 record and a win over the [[Boston College Eagles football|Boston College Eagles]] in the [[Insight.com Bowl]]. As a senior, he started every game at right guard.
Gurode was a first-team All-Big 12 selection in 2000 and 2001, and was recognized as a consensus first-team [[All-America]]n as a senior in 2001.<ref name=ncaarecordsbook>''2011 NCAA Football Records Book'', [http://fs.ncaa.org/Docs/stats/football_records/2011/Awards.pdf Award Winners], National Collegiate Athletic Association, Indianapolis, Indiana, p. 11 (2011). Retrieved June 24, 2012.</ref> During his career he allowed just 7.5 sacks in 2,653 plays as a starter for the Buffaloes.
He earned a degree in ethnic studies from the University of Colorado, where he was a member of the school's "Academic Starters" team.
==Professional career==
===2002 NFL Draft=== Gurode initially projected as a [[Guard (American football)|guard]] and was ranked the best available in the [[2002 NFL Draft]], along with [[Kendall Simmons]].<ref>{{Citation |url=http://www.nfldraftscout.com/ratings/players.php?genpos=OG&draftyear=2002&sortorder=tsxpos&order=ASC |title=2002 Draft OG Ranking |work=NFLDraftScout.com |accessdate=December 25, 2009 }}</ref> He was regarded as an early second round pick,<ref>{{Citation |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/football/2002/draft/players/99600.html |title=Andre Gurode Draft Profile |work=Sports Illustrated |date=April 2002 }}</ref> and was eventually selected 37th overall by the [[Dallas Cowboys]].
{{nfl predraft | height ft = 6 | height in = 4⅜ | weight = 316 | dash = 5.34 | ten split = 1.89 | twenty split = 3.14 | shuttle = 5.05 | cone drill = 8.15 | vertical = 30½ | broad ft = 8 | broad in = 4 | bench = | wonderlic = | arm span = | hand span = | note = All values from [[NFL Combine]]<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.nfldraftscout.com/ratings/dsprofile.php?pyid=59906&draftyear=2002&genpos=OG |title=Andre Gurode Draft Profile |work=NFLDraftScout.com |accessdate=December 25, 2009 }}</ref> }}
===Dallas Cowboys (2002–2010)=== Gurode was [[NFL Draft|drafted]] by the [[Dallas Cowboys]] in the second round of the [[2002 NFL Draft]] as a [[Center (American football)|center]]. He started fast by becoming the first rookie in club history to start at [[Center (American football)|center]] on opening day.
It is believed [[2002 NFL season|2002]] was the first time a [[NFL]] franchise had five African-American starters on their [[offensive line]], when the Cowboys lined up Gurode at [[Center (American and Canadian football)|center]], [[Tackle (American and Canadian football)|tackle]]s [[Flozell Adams]] and [[Solomon Page]], [[Guard (American and Canadian football)|guard]]s [[Larry Allen]] and [[Kelvin Garmon]].<ref>http://a.espncdn.com/nfl/columns/pasquarelli_len/1417470.html</ref> Gurode also became part of history as the starting [[Center (American and Canadian football)|center]] on the Cowboys [[offensive line]] that helped [[Emmitt Smith]] eclipse [[Walter Payton]] as the [[NFL]]'s all-time leading rusher, playing against the [[Seattle Seahawks]] on October 27. While he started the first six games of the [[2002 NFL season|2002 season]] at [[Center (American football)|center]], Gurode was moved to help compensate for the number of injuries along the [[offensive line]], compiling another eight starts at [[Guard (American football)|right guard]].
In [[2003 NFL season|2003]], [[Bill Parcells]] was hired as the Cowboys [[head coach]] and decided that Gurode's best position was at [[Guard (American football)|guard]], starting 15 games at that position in [[2003 NFL season|2003]] and 13 games in [[2004 NFL season|2004]] with mixed results, before getting benched for the final two games.
At the start of the [[2005 NFL season|2005 season]], Parcells accepted he made a misjudgment by moving Gurode to [[Guard (American football)|guard]] and switched him back to [[Center (American football)|center]], with the Cowboys also signing [[Marco Rivera]] to take his place at [[Guard (American football)|guard]]. That season, he was a versatile backup, playing behind [[Al Johnson (guard)|Al Johnson]] at [[Center (American football)|center]] and Rivera at [[Guard (American football)|right guard]].
In [[2006 NFL season|2006]], he rededicated himself to football and won the starting center job again, over [[Al Johnson (guard)|Al Johnson]]. On October 1, [[2006 NFL season|2006]], in the third quarter of a game against the [[Tennessee Titans]], Titans [[defensive tackle]] [[Albert Haynesworth]] stomped on Gurode's head. Haynesworth's cleats caused a laceration requiring thirty stitches.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sportsline.com/nfl/story/9700905 |title=Titans DT Haynesworth nailed with five-game suspension |publisher=Associated Press |work=Sportsline.com |date=October 2, 2006 |accessdate=2008-12-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080628222456/http://sportsline.com/nfl/story/9700905 |archivedate=June 28, 2008 }}</ref> Haynesworth was ejected, and subsequently suspended by the NFL for five games without pay.
Following the [[2006 NFL season|2006 season]], Gurode was named to his first [[2007 Pro Bowl|Pro Bowl]] as an injury replacement. On February 20, [[2007 NFL season|2007]], the Cowboys re-signed Gurode to a six-year contract worth US$30 million including a $10 million signing bonus.
Gurode developed into one of the league's most respected [[Center (American football)|centers]] since returning to being a full-time starter in [[2006 NFL season|2006]], and has been selected to the [[All-Pro]] Team ([[2007 All-Pro Team|2007]], [[2009 All-Pro Team|2009]]), as well as to five straight [[Pro Bowl]]s ([[2006 Pro Bowl|2006]], [[2007 Pro Bowl|2007]], [[2008 Pro Bowl|2008]], [[2009 Pro Bowl|2009]], [[2010 Pro Bowl|2010]])
He had offseason left knee surgery and missed the [[2011 NFL season|2011 season]] training camp and three out of four preseason games. With the emergence of second-year player [[Phil Costa (American football)|Phil Costa]], he was released after the preseason following failed negotiations regarding a restructured contract.<ref>{{cite web|title=Gurode's departure shows Garrett means business |url=http://www.star-telegram.com/2011/08/29/3321072/gurodes-departure-shows-garrett.html?storylink=digger-topic |author=Jaime Aron |date=2011-08-29 |accessdate=2011-09-06}}</ref>
===Baltimore Ravens (2011)=== Gurode reportedly visited the [[Detroit Lions]] and [[New England Patriots]] [http://bleacherbumsports.net/2011/09/02/pats-to-work-out-gurode/] before signing a 1-year, $3 million contract with the [[Baltimore Ravens]] on September 4, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ravens sign Pro Bowl center Andre Gurode to one-year contract |url=http://news.bostonherald.com/sports/football/other_nfl/view/20110905ravens_sign_pro_bowl_center_andre_gurode_to_one-year_contract/srvc=home&position=recent |author=Jamison Hensley |date=2011-09-05 |accessdate=2011-09-06}}</ref>
===Chicago Bears (2012)=== On November 27, 2012, the [[Chicago Bears]] signed Gurode after losing guards [[Lance Louis]] and [[Chris Spencer (American football)|Chris Spencer]] to injuries sustained in a game against the [[Minnesota Vikings]] on November 25.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bears add veteran lineman Gurode |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/football/bears/chi-chicago-bears-sign-andre-gurode-20121127,0,2615470.story |author=Brad Biggs |date=2012-11-27 |accessdate=2012-11-27 |work=Chicago Tribune}}</ref> He was waived by the Bears on December 11, 2012.<ref>{{cite web|last=Mayer|first=Larry|url=http://www.chicagobears.com/news/article-1/Gould-among-three-Bears-played-on-injured-reserve/12d03969-41b4-4d61-8eda-d89419979835|title=Gould among three Bears played on injured reserve|publisher=[[Chicago Bears]]|date=2012-12-11|accessdate=2012-12-11}}</ref>
===Oakland Raiders (2013)=== On July 26, 2013, Gurode signed with the [[Oakland Raiders]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Jerry |last=McDonald |title=Oakland Raiders sign veteran lineman Andre Gurode |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/raiders/ci_23742202/oakland-raiders-sign-veteran-lineman-andre-gurode |work=San Jose Mercury News |date=July 26, 2013}}</ref> At the end of the 2013 NFL season Gurode became a free agent.
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://www.raiders.com/team/roster/Andre-Gurode/32929c77-6c32-4273-8858-c5c5b29fd655 Oakland Raiders bio]

'''Arkady Abramovich Ruderman''' ({{lang-be|Аркадзь Абрамавіч Рудэрман}}, {{lang-ru|Арка́дий Абра́мович Рудерман}}; 7 January 1950 – 22 September 1992) was a [[Belarus]]ian [[documentary films|documentary filmmaker]] who was killed during the [[Civil war in Tajikistan]] in 1992.
==Biography== Arkady Ruderman was born in 1950 in [[Minsk]], capital of the [[Byelorussian SSR]].<ref name=bfi1>{{ cite web | author= | publisher=[[British Film Institute|BFI]] | year= | url=http://ftvdb.bfi.org.uk/sift/individual/201092 | title=Ruderman, Arkady | accessdate=2007-06-25 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.rudata.ru/wiki/%D0%A0%D1%83%D0%B4%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BC%D0%B0%D0%BD,_%D0%90%D1%80%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%90%D0%B1%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%87 Рудерман, Аркадий Абрамович]</ref>
Ruderman first gained fame in the [[Soviet Union]] in 1988 for his reporting on attempts by the [[Communist Party of Belorussia|communist authorities of BSSR]] to play down the [[centennial]] celebration of the [[Jew]]ish [[painting|painter]] [[Marc Chagall]]. Ruderman went on to direct several documentaries about the underside of the Soviet Union. His work won him accolades at the 1988 and 1989 [[Cinema of the Soviet Union|Soviet film festivals]]. In November 1988 Ruderman was the first Russian TV journalist to interview [[Alexander Dubček]], the former leader of [[Czechoslovakia]] who was deposed by Soviet forces after the [[Prague Spring]] uprising of 1968.<ref name=rfe>{{ cite web |author= |publisher=[[Radio Free Europe]] |year=1992 |url=http://www.friends-partners.org/friends/news/omri/1992/09/920925.html(opt,mozilla,unix,english,,new) |title=Belorussian Film Director Shot In Tajikistan |accessdate=2007-06-22 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040122085947/http://www.friends-partners.org/friends/news/omri/1992/09/920925.html%28opt%2Cmozilla%2Cunix%2Cenglish%2C%2Cnew%29 |archivedate=2004-01-22 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
In September 1992 Ruderman traveled to [[Tajikistan]] to film a documentary for [[Channel One (Russia)|Ostankino]] about [[Davlat Khudonazarov]], a fellow filmmaker and opposition candidate in the [[Tajikistani presidential election, 1991|1991 Tajikistani presidential elections]]. At the time the [[Civil war in Tajikistan]] was raging and journalists had become the target of murder. On 22 September 1992 Ruderman was killed while traveling by car along the road from [[Nurek Dam]] to the capital [[Dushanbe]], an area that at the time was experiencing heavy fighting between government and opposition forces. The government ruled Ruderman's death a vehicular accident, but the circumstances surrounding his death remain a mystery and his name is listed by the [[Center for Journalism in Extreme Situations]] as one of the journalists murdered in Tajikistan.<ref name=cjes2>{{ cite web | author= | publisher=[[Center for Journalism in Extreme Situations]] | year= | url=http://www.memorium.cjes.ru/?pid=2&id=276 | title= Memorium | accessdate=2007-06-25 }}</ref><ref name=cjes1>{{ cite web |author= |publisher=[[Center for Journalism in Extreme Situations]] |year=2003 |url=http://www.cjes.ru/lenta/view_news.php?id=892&year=2003&lang=eng |title=CJES/Tadjikistan |accessdate=2007-06-22 }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Filmography== * 1989 - ''Recrimination''<ref name=interfilm>{{ cite web |author= |publisher=[[INTERFILM]] |year= |url=http://www.inter-film.org/pdf/Databank_Ron_Holloway.pdf |title=Databank: copyright Ron Holloway |accessdate=2007-06-25 |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927072810/http://www.inter-film.org/pdf/Databank_Ron_Holloway.pdf |archivedate=2007-09-27 |df= }}</ref> or ''The Counter-claim''<ref name=vertov>{{ cite web | author= | publisher=Vertov | year= | url= http://www.vertov.ru/eng/festivals.htm | title= Festivals in Russia | accessdate=2007-06-25 }}</ref> with [[Yury Khashchevatsky]]. * 1985 - ''Who Will Correct Demeter's Error?'' (''Kto Ispravit Oshibku Demetry?'')<ref name=bfi2>{{ cite web | author= | publisher=[[British Film Institute|BFI]] | year= | url= http://ftvdb.bfi.org.uk/sift/title/258025 | title= Kto Ispravit Oshibku Demetry | accessdate=2007-06-25 }}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of journalists killed in Tajikistan]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == *[http://www.memorium.cjes.ru/?pid=2&id=276 Memorium page at CJES for Arcady Ruderman (Russian)]
