revision.comment: clean up, [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: Blacksmith’s → Blacksmith's
revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=June 2018}} {{Superherobox| <!--Wikipedia:WikiProject Comics--> image= | caption = | character_name = Blacksmith | real_name = Amunet Black |species = [[Metahuman]] | publisher = [[DC Comics]] | debut = ''Flash: Iron Heights'' (2001) | creators = [[Geoff Johns]], [[Ethan Van Sciver]] | alliances = [[Enemies of the Flash|The Rogues]] | previous_alliances = | aliases = | partners = Keith Kenyon ([[Goldface]], ex-husband) | powers = Merge metal with flesh and shape it to her will }} '''Blacksmith''' is a [[DC Comics]] [[supervillain]] and a [[Enemies of the Flash|rogue]] to [[Flash (comics)|the Flash III]] ([[Wally West]]). She first appeared in ''Flash: [[Iron Heights]]'' (2001).
==Fictional character biography== For 15 years, '''Amunet Black''' has been running and operating the '''[[List of criminal organizations in DC Comics#Network II|Network]]''' an underground black market in [[Central City (DC Comics)|Central]] and [[Keystone City]], the twin cities, for supervillains to buy, sell, or move contraband. During that time, she had a brief marriage to [[Goldface]]. When they divorced, she stole the elixir that gave him his powers and changed it to gain the ability to merge metal with flesh and shape it to her will. She was able to keep the Network hidden from the authorities and if any villain reformed or quit crime, she made sure the memories of the Network were erased from their minds. When her ex-husband and criminal profiler Hunter Zolomon (the future [[Zoom (comics)|Zoom]]) were about to find out about the Network, she sent [[Trickster (comics)|the Trickster II]] to stop them. Soon, with a vision of power, Blacksmith planned out her takeover of the twin cities, with her as the leader.
First, she organized a new group of rogues, which consisted of the [[Weather Wizard]], [[Mirror Master]] II, [[Magenta (comics)|Magenta]], [[Murmur (DC Comics)|Murmur]], [[Girder (comics)|Girder]], [[Plunder (comics)|Plunder]], and Trickster II. She made sure that her rogues were strong and had better control of their powers. She had Magenta use her powers to keep Girder from rusting and taught the Weather Wizard better control with his wand.
Second, she and her rogues had Flash's allies removed or incapacitated. Mirror Master framed [[Pied Piper (comics)|Piper]] for the murder of his parents. Plunder took out [[Chunk (comics)|Chunk]], shot his mirror image, Detective Jared Morillo, and assumed his identity. Then, Mirror Master kidnapped [[Cyborg (comics)|Cyborg]] and police officer Fred Chyre, trapping them in a mirror universe along with all the other cops of Keystone City. The Rogues then removed the speedsters by giving [[Jesse Quick]]'s company financial trouble and then sent [[Jay Garrick]] to a hospital in [[Denver]] when his wife got sick.
Finally, Murmur and Mirror Master attacked radio stations and reprogrammed their antennas to broadcast a mirror shield around the twin cities to prevent anyone from coming in or getting out.
After everything had been put into place, Blacksmith and her rogues launched their takeover and began by attacking the Flash. They attacked hard and fast, which left Flash tired and badly injured, but just as they were about to finish him off, they were stopped by [[Thinker (DC Comics)|the Thinker]], who wanted to use the Flash's brain to upload information. After the Thinker was defeated, Blacksmith and the rogues resumed their plan and attacked Flash and Goldface. They successfully trounced Flash while Goldface escaped. During the fight, Blacksmith used her power to transform her body into ebony metal, while villains in the Network began to loot and pillage the two cities. Luckily, Goldface lead the people of the twin cities against the Network and Flash managed to defeat the Weather Wizard, Mirror Master, and Trickster II, before they escaped when [[Captain Cold]] froze the ground and Mirror Master used it to retreat. With her rogues defeated, she tried a desperate attack by collapsing the bridge that connects Keystone City and Central City. The Flash quickly managed to rebuild the bridge and finally defeat Blacksmith by stranding her on a barge in the middle of the river (she could not enter the water for fear of rusting her metal skin). With her Network discontinued, she was sent to Iron Heights, where she was severely wounded by the escaping [[Gorilla Grodd]]. Although she survived her injuries, Blacksmith has not been seen since that incident, although she did show up for [[Captain Boomerang|"Digger" Harkness]]' funeral.
==Powers and abilities==
Blacksmith's body has been mutated to be the perfect fusion between organic and inorganic. This has given her the ability to fuse organic and inorganic matter. Blacksmith has used the ability to fuse an inorganic object into an opponent causing serious damage. Blacksmith has also used the ability to cause serious damage to inorganic structures.
==In other media== [[Katee Sackhoff]] portrays Amunet Black aka Blacksmith in season four of ''[[The Flash (2014 TV series)|The Flash]]''.
==External links== *[http://www.hyperborea.org/flash/blacksmith.html Profile from "The Flash: Those Who Ride The Lightning" website] *[http://www.fourthhorsemanpress.com/Flash/ Crimson Lightning] - An online index to the comic book adventures of the Flash.
{{Flash}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Blacksmith (Comics)}} [[Category:DC Comics supervillains]] [[Category:Fictional cyborgs]] [[Category:Fictional inventors]] [[Category:Comics characters introduced in 2001]] [[Category:Characters created by Geoff Johns]] [[Category:Female characters in comics]]

{{taxobox | regnum = [[Fungi]] | subdivisio = [[Mucoromycotina]] | ordo = [[Mucorales]] | familia = [[Cunninghamellaceae]] | genus = ''[[Cunninghamella]]'' | species = '''''C. elegans''''' | binomial = ''Cunninghamella elegans'' | binomial_authority = [[Alfred Lendner|Lendner]] (1907){{cite journal |author=Lendner A. |title=Sur quelques Mucorinées |journal=Bulletin de l´Herbier Boissier |year=1907 |volume=7 |issue=3 |pages=249–51 |url=https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/33743763 |language=French}} | synonyms = * ''Cunninghamella echinulata'' var. ''elegans'' (Lendner) Lunn & Shipton{{cite journal |author=Weitzmann I. |title=The case for ''Cunninghamella elegans'', ''C. bertholletiae'' and ''C. echinulata'' as separate species |journal=Transactions of the British Mycological Society |year=1984 |volume=83 |issue=3 |pages=527–529 |doi=10.1016/S0007-1536(84)80056-X |url=http://www.cybertruffle.org.uk/cyberliber/59351/0083/003/0527.htm}} * ''Cunninghamella elegans var. elegans'' Lendn. 1905 }} '''''Cunninghamella elegans''''' is a species of [[fungus]] in the genus ''[[Cunninghamella]]'' found in soil.{{Cite journal | last1 = Zhu | first1 = Y. Z. | last2 = Keum | first2 = Y. S. | last3 = Yang | first3 = L. | last4 = Lee | first4 = H. | last5 = Park | first5 = H. | last6 = Kim | first6 = J. H. | doi = 10.1021/jf102980y | title = Metabolism of a Fungicide Mepanipyrim by Soil FungusCunninghamella elegansATCC36112 | journal = Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry | volume = 58 | issue = 23 | pages = 12379–12384 | year = 2010 | pmid = 21047134| pmc = }} It can be grown in [[Raymond Sabouraud|Sabouraud]] dextrose broth, a liquid medium used for cultivation of yeasts and molds from liquid which are normally sterile. As opposed to ''[[Cunninghamella bertholletiae|C. bertholletiae]]'', it is not a [[human pathogen]],{{Cite journal | last1 = Weitzman | first1 = I. | last2 = Crist | first2 = M. Y. | title = Studies with clinical isolates of Cunninghamella. I. Mating behavior | journal = Mycologia | volume = 71 | issue = 5 | pages = 1024–1033 | year = 1979 | pmid = 545137 |jstor=3759290 | doi=10.2307/3759290 }} with the exception of two documented patients.{{Cite journal | last1 = Kwon-Chung | first1 = K. J. | last2 = Young | first2 = R. C. | last3 = Orlando | first3 = M. | title = Pulmonary mucormycosis caused by Cunninghamella elegans in a patient with chronic myelogenous leukemia | journal = American journal of clinical pathology | volume = 64 | issue = 4 | pages = 544–548 | year = 1975 | pmid = 1060379 }} == Description == ''C. elegans'' is a filamentous fungus that produces purely gray colonies. Electron microscopy studies show that the [[conidium|conidia]] are covered with spines.{{Cite journal | last1 = Hawker | first1 = L. E. | last2 = Thomas | first2 = B. | last3 = Beckett | first3 = A. | doi = 10.1099/00221287-60-2-181 | title = An Electron Microscope Study of Structure and Germination of Conidia of Cunninghamella elegans Lendner | journal = Microbiology | volume = 60 | issue = 2 | pages = 181–189 | year = 1970 | pmid = | pmc = }} == Use as a fungal organism capable of xenobiotics metabolism == ''Cunninghamella elegans'' is able to degrade [[xenobiotic]]s.{{Cite journal | last1 = Wackett | first1 = L. P. | last2 = Gibson | first2 = D. T. | title = Metabolism of xenobiotic compounds by enzymes in cell extracts of the fungus Cunninghamella elegans | journal = The Biochemical Journal | volume = 205 | issue = 1 | pages = 117–122 | year = 1982 | pmid = 6812568 | pmc = 1158453 | doi=10.1042/bj2050117 }} It has a variety of enzymes of phases I (modification enzymes acting to introduce reactive and polar groups into their substrates) and II (conjugation enzymes) of the [[xenobiotic metabolism]], as do mammals. [[Cytochrome P450 monooxygenase]], [[aryl sulfotransferase]], [[glutathione S-transferase]], [[UDP-glucuronosyltransferase]], [[UDP-glucosyltransferase]] activities have been detected in cytosolic or microsomal fractions.{{Cite journal | last1 = Zhang | first1 = D. | last2 = Yang | first2 = Y. | last3 = Leakey | first3 = J. E. A. | last4 = Cerniglia | first4 = C. E. | title = Phase I and phase II enzymes produced byCunninghamella elegansfor the metabolism of xenobiotics | doi = 10.1111/j.1574-6968.1996.tb08161.x | journal = FEMS Microbiology Letters | volume = 138 | issue = 2–3 | pages = 221–226 | year = 1996 | pmid = 9026450| pmc = }} [[Cytochrome P450 monooxygenase|Cytochrome P-450]] and [[cytochrome P-450 reductase]] in ''C. elegans'' are part of the phase I enzymes. They are induced by the corticosteroid [[cortexolone]] and by [[phenanthrene]].{{Cite journal|last1=Lisowska|first1=K.|last2=Szemraj|first2=J.|last3=Rózalska|first3=S.|last4=Długoński|first4=J.|date=|year=2006|title=The expression of cytochrome P-450 and cytochrome P-450 reductase genes in the simultaneous transformation of corticosteroids and phenanthrene byCunninghamella elegans|url=|journal=FEMS Microbiology Letters|volume=261|issue=2|pages=175–180|doi=10.1111/j.1574-6968.2006.00339.x|pmc=|pmid=16907717|via=}} ''C. elegans'' also possesses a [[lanosterol 14-alpha demethylase]], another enzyme in the cytochrome P450 family.[https://www.uniprot.org/uniprot/Q9UVC3 Lanosterol 14-alpha demethylase from ''Cunninghamella elegans'' on www.uniprot.org] ''C. elegans'' also possesses a [[glutathione S-transferase]].{{Cite journal | last1 = Cha | first1 = C. J. | last2 = Kim | first2 = S. J. | last3 = Kim | first3 = Y. H. | last4 = Stingley | first4 = R. | last5 = Cerniglia | first5 = C. E. | title = Molecular cloning, expression and characterization of a novel class glutathione S-transferase from the fungus Cunninghamella elegans | doi = 10.1042/BJ20020400 | journal = Biochemical Journal | volume = 368 | issue = 2 | pages = 589 | year = 2002 | pmid = 12196209| pmc = 1223007}} === Use as a fungal model organism of mammalian drug metabolism === ''Cunninghamella elegans'' is a microbial [[model organism|model]] of mammalian drug metabolism.{{cite journal |author1=Kristian Björnstad |author2=Anders Helander |author3=Peter Hultén |author4=Olof Beck |year=2009 |title=Bioanalytical investigation of asarone in connection with ''Acorus calamus'' oil intoxications |journal=[[Journal of Analytical Toxicology]] |volume=33 |issue=9 |pages=604–609 |url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/pres/jat/2009/00000033/00000009/art00005 |doi=10.1093/jat/33.9.604 |pmid=20040135}}{{cite journal |author1=Joanna D. Moody |author2=Donglu Zhang |author3=Thomas M. Heinze |author4=Carl E. Cerniglia |year=2000 |title=Transformation of amoxapine by ''Cunninghamella elegans'' |journal=[[Applied and Environmental Microbiology]] |volume=66 |issue=8 |pages=3646–3649 |pmc=92200 |pmid=10919836 |doi=10.1128/AEM.66.8.3646-3649.2000}}{{cite journal |author1=A. Jaworski |author2=L. Sedlaczek |author3=J. Dlugoński |author4=Ewa Zajaczkowska |year=1985 |title=Inducible nature of the steroid 11-hydroxylases in spores of ''Cunninghamella elegans'' (Lendner) |journal=[[Journal of Basic Microbiology]] |volume=25 |issue=7 |pages=423–427 |doi=10.1002/jobm.3620250703}}{{Cite journal | last1 = Hezari | first1 = M. | last2 = Davis | first2 = P. J. | title = Microbial models of mammalian metabolism. Furosemide glucoside formation using the fungus Cunninghamella elegans | journal = Drug Metabolism and Disposition | volume = 21 | issue = 2 | pages = 259–267 | year = 1993 | pmid = 8097695 }} The use of this fungus could reduce the over-all need for [[laboratory animal]]s.{{Cite journal|doi=10.4103/0250-474X.89750|pmc=3224398|title=Substitute of animals in drug research: An approach towards fulfillment of 4R′s|year=2011|last1=Sharma|first1=KK|last2=Mehta|first2=T|last3=Joshi|first3=V|last4=Mehta|first4=N|last5=Rathor|first5=AK|last6=Mediratta|first6=KD|last7=Sharma|first7=PK|journal=Indian Journal of Pharmaceutical Sciences|volume=73|pages=1–6|pmid=22131615|issue=1}} ''C. elegans'' is able to transform the tricyclic antidepressants [[amitriptyline]]{{Cite journal | last1 = Zhang | first1 = D. | last2 = Evans | first2 = F. E. | last3 = Freeman | first3 = J. P. | last4 = Duhart Jr | first4 = B. | last5 = Cerniglia | first5 = C. E. | title = Biotransformation of amitriptyline by Cunninghamella elegans | journal = Drug Metabolism and Disposition | volume = 23 | issue = 12 | pages = 1417–1425 | year = 1995 | pmid = 8689954 }} and [[doxepin]],{{Cite journal | last1 = Moody | first1 = J. D. | last2 = Freeman | first2 = J. P. | last3 = Cerniglia | first3 = C. E. | title = Biotransformation of doxepin by Cunninghamella elegans | journal = Drug Metabolism and Disposition | volume = 27 | issue = 10 | pages = 1157–1164 | year = 1999 | pmid = 10497142 }} the tetracyclic antidepressant [[mirtazapine]],{{Cite journal | last1 = Moody | first1 = J. D. | last2 = Freeman | first2 = J. P. | last3 = Fu | first3 = P. P. | last4 = Cerniglia | first4 = C. E. | title = Biotransformation of Mirtazapine by Cunninghamella Elegans | doi = 10.1124/dmd.30.11.1274 | journal = Drug Metabolism and Disposition | volume = 30 | issue = 11 | pages = 1274–1279 | year = 2002 | pmid = 12386135| pmc = }} the muscle relaxant [[cyclobenzaprine]],{{Cite journal | last1 = Zhang | first1 = D. | last2 = Evans | first2 = F. E. | last3 = Freeman | first3 = J. P. | last4 = Yang | first4 = Y. | last5 = Deck | first5 = J. | last6 = Cerniglia | first6 = C. E. | doi = 10.1016/S0009-2797(96)03736-2 | title = Formation of mammalian metabolites of cyclobenzaprine by the fungus, Cunninghamella elegans | journal = Chemico-Biological Interactions | volume = 102 | issue = 2 | pages = 79–92 | year = 1996 | pmid = 8950223| pmc = }} the typical antipsychotic [[chlorpromazine]] as well as the antihistamine and anticholinergic [[methdilazine]]{{Cite journal | last1 = Zhang | first1 = D. | last2 = Freeman | first2 = J. P. | last3 = Sutherland | first3 = J. B. | last4 = Walker | first4 = A. E. | last5 = Yang | first5 = Y. | last6 = Cerniglia | first6 = C. E. | title = Biotransformation of chlorpromazine and methdilazine by Cunninghamella elegans | journal = Applied and Environmental Microbiology | volume = 62 | issue = 3 | pages = 798–803 | year = 1996 | pmid = 8975609 | pmc = 167846 }} and [[azatadine]]. It is also able to transform the antihistamines [[brompheniramine]], [[chlorpheniramine]] and [[pheniramine]].{{Cite journal | last1 = Hansen | first1 = E. B. | last2 = Cho | first2 = B. P. | last3 = Korfmacher | first3 = W. A. | last4 = Cerniglia | first4 = C. E. | title = Fungal transformations of antihistamines: Metabolism of brompheniramine, chlorpheniramine, and pheniramine toN-oxide andN-demethylated metabolites by the fungusCunninghamella elegans | doi = 10.3109/00498259509061908 | journal = Xenobiotica | volume = 25 | issue = 10 | pages = 1081–1092 | year = 1995 | pmid = 8578764| pmc = }} It forms a [[glucoside]] with the diuretic [[furosemide]]. The transformation of oral contraceptive [[mestranol]] by ''C. elegans'' yields two hydroxylated metabolites, [[6beta-hydroxymestranol]] and [[6beta,12beta-dihydroxymestranol]].{{Cite journal | last1 = Choudhary | first1 = M. I. | last2 = Musharraf | first2 = S. G. | last3 = Siddiqui | first3 = Z. A. | last4 = Khan | first4 = N. T. | last5 = Ali | first5 = R. A. | last6 = Ur-Rahman | first6 = A. | title = Microbial transformation of mestranol by Cunninghamella elegans | journal = Chemical & Pharmaceutical Bulletin | volume = 53 | issue = 8 | pages = 1011–1013 | year = 2005 | pmid = 16079537 | doi=10.1248/cpb.53.1011 }} === Metabolism of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons === The phase I [[Cytochrome P450 monooxygenase|cytochrome P450]] enzyme systems of ''C. elegans'' has been implicated in the neutralization of numerous [[polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon]]s (PAH). It can degrade molecules such as [[anthracene]], 7-methylbenz[a]anthracene and 7-hydroxymethylbenz[a]anthracene,{{Cite journal | last1 = Cerniglia | first1 = C. E. | last2 = Fu | first2 = P. P. | last3 = Yang | first3 = S. K. | title = Metabolism of 7-methylbenzaanthracene and 7-hydroxymethylbenzaanthracene by Cunninghamella elegans | journal = Applied and Environmental Microbiology | volume = 44 | issue = 3 | pages = 682–689 | year = 1982 | pmid = 7138006 | pmc = 242076 }} [[phenanthrene]],{{Cite journal | last1 = Cerniglia | first1 = C. E. | last2 = Yang | first2 = S. K. | title = Stereoselective metabolism of anthracene and phenanthrene by the fungus Cunninghamella elegans | journal = Applied and Environmental Microbiology | volume = 47 | issue = 1 | pages = 119–124 | year = 1984 | pmid = 6696409 | pmc = 239622 }} [[acenaphthene]],{{Cite journal | last1 = Pothuluri | first1 = J. V. | last2 = Freeman | first2 = J. P. | last3 = Evans | first3 = F. E. | last4 = Cerniglia | first4 = C. E. | title = Fungal metabolism of acenaphthene by Cunninghamella elegans | journal = Applied and Environmental Microbiology | volume = 58 | issue = 11 | pages = 3654–3659 | year = 1992 | pmid = 1482186 | pmc = 183157 }} [[1-methylnaphthalene|1-]] and [[2-methylnaphthalene]],{{Cite journal | last1 = Cerniglia | first1 = C. E. | last2 = Lambert | first2 = K. J. | last3 = Miller | first3 = D. W. | last4 = Freeman | first4 = J. P. | title = Transformation of 1- and 2-methylnaphthalene by Cunninghamella elegans | journal = Applied and Environmental Microbiology | volume = 47 | issue = 1 | pages = 111–118 | year = 1984 | pmid = 6696408 | pmc = 239621 }} [[naphthalene]],{{Cite journal | last1 = Cerniglia | first1 = C. E. | last2 = Gibson | first2 = D. T. | title = Metabolism of naphthalene by Cunninghamella elegans | journal = Applied and Environmental Microbiology | volume = 34 | issue = 4 | pages = 363–370 | year = 1977 | pmid = 921262 | pmc = 242664 }} [[fluorene]]{{Cite journal | last1 = Pothuluri | first1 = J. V. | last2 = Freeman | first2 = J. P. | last3 = Evans | first3 = F. E. | last4 = Cerniglia | first4 = C. E. | title = Biotransformation of fluorene by the fungus Cunninghamella elegans | journal = Applied and Environmental Microbiology | volume = 59 | issue = 6 | pages = 1977–1980 | year = 1993 | pmid = 8328814 | pmc = 182201 }} or [[benzo(a)pyrene]].{{Cite journal | last1 = Cerniglia | first1 = C. E. | last2 = Mahaffey | first2 = W. | last3 = Gibson | first3 = D. T. | doi = 10.1016/S0006-291X(80)80210-5 | title = Fungal oxidation of benzo\a]pyrene: Formation of (−)-trans-7,8-dihydroxy-7,8-dihydrobenzo\a]pyrene by Cunninghamella elegans | journal = Biochemical and Biophysical Research Communications | volume = 94 | issue = 1 | pages = 226–232 | year = 1980 | pmid = 7190014| pmc = }} In the case of phenanthrene, ''C. elegans'' produces a [[glucoside]] [[conjugation (biochemistry)|conjugate]] of [[1-hydroxyphenanthrene]] ([[phenanthrene 1-O-beta-glucose]]).{{Cite journal | last1 = Cerniglia | first1 = C. E. | last2 = Campbell | first2 = W. L. | last3 = Freeman | first3 = J. P. | last4 = Evans | first4 = F. E. | title = Identification of a novel metabolite in phenanthrene metabolism by the fungus Cunninghamella elegans | journal = Applied and Environmental Microbiology | volume = 55 | issue = 9 | pages = 2275–2279 | year = 1989 | pmid = 2802607 | pmc = 203068 }} === Metabolism of pesticides === ''C. elegans'' is also able to degrade the herbicides [[alachlor]],{{Cite journal | last1 = Pothuluri | first1 = J. V. | last2 = Freeman | first2 = J. P. | last3 = Evans | first3 = F. E. | last4 = Moorman | first4 = T. B. | last5 = Cerniglia | first5 = C. E. | title = Metabolism of alachlor by the fungus Cunninghamella elegans | doi = 10.1021/jf00027a026 | journal = Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry | volume = 41 | issue = 3 | pages = 483–488 | year = 1993 | pmid = | pmc = }} [[metolachlor]]{{cite journal |author1=Jairaj V. Pothuluri, Frederick E. Evans |author2=Doerge, D.R. |author3=Churchwell, M.I. |author4= Carl E. Cerniglia |last-author-amp=yes| year = 1997 | title = Metabolism of metolachlor by the fungus ''Cunninghamella elegans'' | journal = Arch. Environ. Contam. Toxicol. | volume = 32 | pages = 117–125 | doi = 10.1007/s002449900163 | pmid = 9069185 | issue = 2}} and [[isoproturon]]{{Cite journal | last1 = Hangler | first1 = M. | last2 = Jensen | first2 = B. | last3 = Rønhede | first3 = S. | last4 = Sørensen | first4 = S. R. | title = Inducible hydroxylation and demethylation of the herbicide isoproturon by Cunninghamella elegans | doi = 10.1111/j.1574-6968.2006.00599.x | journal = FEMS Microbiology Letters | volume = 268 | issue = 2 | pages = 254–260 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17328751 | pmc = }} as well as the fungicide [[mepanipyrim]]. === Metabolism of phenolics === ''Cunninghamella elegans'' can be used to study the metabolism of phenols. This type of molecules already have reactive and polar groups comprised within their structure therefore phases I enzymes are less active than phase II (conjugation) enzymes. ==== Metabolism of flavonoids ==== ; Flavonols In flavonols, an hydroxyl group is available in the 3- position allowing the [[glycosylation]] at that position. The biotransformation of [[quercetin]] yields three metabolites, including [[quercetin 3-O-β-D-glucopyranoside]], [[kaempferol 3-O-β-D-glucopyranoside]] and [[isorhamnetin 3-O-β-D-glucopyranoside]]. Glucosylation and O-methylation are involved in the process. ; Flavones In flavones, there is no hydroxyl group available at the 3- position. Conjugation, in the form of [[sulfation]] occurs at the 7- or 4'- positions. [[Apigenin]] and [[chrysin]] are also transformed by ''C. elegans'' and produce [[apigenin 7-sulfate]], [[apigenin 7,4′-disulfate]], [[chrysin 7-sulfate]].{{Cite journal | last1 = Ibrahim | first1 = A. R. S. | title = Biotransformation of Chrysin and Apigenin by Cunninghamella elegans | doi = 10.1248/cpb.53.671 | journal = Chemical & Pharmaceutical Bulletin | volume = 53 | issue = 6 | pages = 671–672 | year = 2005 | pmid = 15930780| pmc = }}
[[Sulfation]] also occurs on [[naringenin]] and produces [[naringenin-7-sulfate]].{{cite journal |author=Abdel-Rahim S. Ibrahim |year=2000 |title=Sulfation of naringenin by ''Cunninghamella elegans'' |journal=[[Phytochemistry (journal)|Phytochemistry]] |volume=53 |issue=2 |pages=209–212 |doi=10.1016/S0031-9422(99)00487-2 |pmid=10680173}} Glucosylation may nevertheless occur but in 3'- position, as happens during the microbial transformation of [[psiadiarabin]] and its 6-desmethoxy analogue, [[5,3′ dihydroxy-7,2′,4′,5′-tetramethoxyflavone]], by ''Cunninghamella elegans'' NRRL 1392 that gives the 3′-glucoside conjugates of the two flavones.{{Cite journal | last1 = Ibrahim | first1 = A. R. | last2 = Galal | first2 = A. M. | last3 = Mossa | first3 = J. S. | last4 = El-Feraly | first4 = F. S. | title = Glucose-conjugation of the flavones of Psiadia arabica by Cunninghamella elegans | journal = Phytochemistry | volume = 46 | issue = 7 | pages = 1193–1195 | year = 1997 | pmid = 9423290 | doi=10.1016/s0031-9422(97)00421-4 }} ; flavanones As in flavones, there is no hydroxyl groups available at the 3- position for glycosylation in flavanones. Therefore, sulfation occurs at the 7- position. In compounds like 7-methoxylated flavanones like 7-O-methylnaringenin ([[sakuranetin]]), [[demethylation]] followed by [[sulfation]] occur.{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1248/cpb.51.203 | last1 = Ibrahim | first1 = A. R. | last2 = Galal | first2 = A. M. | last3 = Ahmed | first3 = M. S. | last4 = Mossa | first4 = G. S. | title = O-demethylation and sulfation of 7-methoxylated flavanones by Cunninghamella elegans | journal = Chemical & Pharmaceutical Bulletin | volume = 51 | issue = 2 | pages = 203–206 | year = 2003 | pmid = 12576658 |id= {{INIST|14569933}} }} ==== Metabolism of synthetic phenolics ==== It is also able to degrade synthetic phenolic compounds like [[bisphenol A]].{{Cite journal | last1 = Keum | first1 = Y. S. | last2 = Lee | first2 = H. R. | last3 = Park | first3 = H. W. | last4 = Kim | first4 = J. H. | title = Biodegradation of bisphenol a and its halogenated analogues by Cunninghamella elegans ATCC36112 | doi = 10.1007/s10532-010-9358-8 | journal = Biodegradation | volume = 21 | issue = 6 | pages = 989–997 | year = 2010 | pmid = 20455075| pmc = }} === Metabolism of heterocyclic organic compounds === ''C. elegans'' can transform the nitrogen containing compound [[phthalazine]]{{cite journal | last1 = Sutherland | first1 = John B. | last2 = Freeman | first2 = James P. | last3 = Williams | first3 = Anna J. | last4 = Deck | first4 = Joanna | year = 1999 | title = Biotransformation of Phthalazine by Fusarium moniliforme and Cunninghamela elegans | url = https://zenodo.org/record/1235153/files/article.pdf| journal = Mycologia | volume = 91 | issue = | pages = 114–116 | jstor = 3761198 | doi=10.2307/3761198}} It is also able to oxidize the [[organosulfur]] compound [[dibenzothiophene]].{{Cite journal | last1 = Crawford | first1 = D. L. | last2 = Gupta | first2 = R. K. | doi = 10.1007/BF02092161 | title = Oxidation of dibenzothiophene byCunninghamella elegans | journal = Current Microbiology | volume = 21 | issue = 4 | pages = 229–231 | year = 1990 | pmid = | pmc = }} == Uses in biotechnology == Methods for efficient ''C. elegans'' genomic DNA isolation and transformation have been developed.{{Cite journal | last1 = Zhang | first1 = D. | last2 = Yang | first2 = Y. | last3 = Castlebury | first3 = L. A. | last4 = Cerniglia | first4 = C. E. | title = A method for the large scale isolation of high transformation efficiency fungal genomic DNA | doi = 10.1111/j.1574-6968.1996.tb08587.x | journal = FEMS Microbiology Letters | volume = 145 | issue = 2 | pages = 261–265 | year = 1996 | pmid = 8961565| pmc = }} The cytochrome P450 of ''C. elegans'' has been cloned in ''[[Escherichia coli]]''{{Cite journal | last1 = Wang | first1 = R. F. | last2 = Cao | first2 = W. W. | last3 = Khan | first3 = A. A. | last4 = Cerniglia | first4 = C. E. | title = Cloning, sequencing, and expression inEscherichia coliof a cytochrome P450 gene fromCunninghamella elegans | doi = 10.1111/j.1574-6968.2000.tb09168.x | journal = FEMS Microbiology Letters | volume = 188 | issue = 1 | pages = 55–61 | year = 2000 | pmid = 10867234| pmc = }} as well as an [[enolase]].{{Cite journal | last1 = Wang | first1 = R. F. | last2 = Khan | first2 = A. A. | last3 = Cao | first3 = W. W. | last4 = Cerniglia | first4 = C. E. | title = Cloning, sequencing, and expression of the gene encoding enolase from Cunninghamella elegans | doi = 10.1017/S0953756299001112 | journal = Mycological Research | volume = 104 | issue = 2 | pages = 175–179 | year = 2000 | pmid = | pmc = }} === Use in bioconversion === ==== Techniques employed ==== ''Cunninghamella elegans'' can be grown in [[stirred tank batch bioreactor]].{{Cite journal | last1 = Lisowska | first1 = K. | last2 = Bizukojc | first2 = M. | last3 = Długoński | first3 = J. | doi = 10.1016/j.enzmictec.2006.03.039 | title = An unstructured model for studies on phenanthrene bioconversion by filamentous fungus Cunninghamella elegans | journal = Enzyme and Microbial Technology | volume = 39 | issue = 7 | pages = 1464–1470 | year = 2006 | pmid = | pmc = }} [[Protoplast]]s cultures have been used.{{Cite journal | last1 = Długoński | first1 = J. | last2 = Sedlaczek | first2 = L. | last3 = Jaworski | first3 = A. | doi = 10.1139/m84-010 | title = Protoplast release from fungi capable of steroid transformation | journal = Canadian Journal of Microbiology | volume = 30 | issue = 1 | pages = 57–62 | year = 1984 | pmid = 6713303| pmc = }} (French) ==== Examples of uses ==== ''C. elegans'' can be used for [[phenanthrene]] bioconversion or for [[steroid]] transformation. It has been used to produce [[isoapocodeine]] from [[10,11-dimethoxyaporphine]],{{Cite journal | last1 = Smith | first1 = R. V. | last2 = Davis | first2 = P. J. | title = Regiospecific synthesis of isoapocodeine from 10,11-dimethoxyaporphine by using Cunninghamella elegans | journal = Applied and Environmental Microbiology | volume = 35 | issue = 4 | pages = 738–742 | year = 1978 | pmid = 25623 | pmc = 242915 }} [[triptoquinone]] from the synthetic abietane diterpene [[triptophenolide]]T{{Cite journal | last1 = Milanova | first1 = R. | last2 = Stoynov | first2 = N. | last3 = Moore | first3 = M. | doi = 10.1016/0141-0229(95)00184-0 | title = The optimization of triptoquinone production by Cunninghamella elegans using factorial design | journal = Enzyme and Microbial Technology | volume = 19 | issue = 2 | pages = 86–93 | year = 1996 | pmid = | pmc = }} or for the rational and economical bioconversion of antimalarial drug [[artemisinin]] to [[7beta-hydroxyartemisinin]].{{Cite journal | last1 = Parshikov | first1 = I. A. | last2 = Muraleedharan | first2 = K. M. | last3 = Avery | first3 = M. A. | last4 = Williamson | first4 = J. S. | title = Transformation of artemisinin by Cunninghamella elegans | doi = 10.1007/s00253-003-1524-z | journal = Applied Microbiology and Biotechnology | volume = 64 | issue = 6 | pages = 782–786 | year = 2004 | pmid = 14735322 | pmc = }} === Environmental biotechnology === ''Cunninghamella elegans'' has been used in [[environmental biotechnology]] for the treatment of textile [[wastewater]]s,{{Cite journal | last1 = Tigini | first1 = V. | last2 = Prigione | first2 = V. | last3 = Donelli | first3 = I. | last4 = Anastasi | first4 = A. | last5 = Freddi | first5 = G. | last6 = Giansanti | first6 = P. | last7 = Mangiavillano | first7 = A. | last8 = Varese | first8 = G. C. | doi = 10.1007/s00253-010-3010-8 | title = Cunninghamella elegans biomass optimisation for textile wastewater biosorption treatment: An analytical and ecotoxicological approach | journal = Applied Microbiology and Biotechnology | volume = 90 | issue = 1 | pages = 343–352 | year = 2010 | pmid = 21127858| pmc = }} for instance those discoloured by [[azo dye]]s or [[malachite green]].{{Cite journal | last1 = Cha | first1 = C. -J. | last2 = Doerge | first2 = D. R. | last3 = Cerniglia | first3 = C. E. | doi = 10.1128/AEM.67.9.4358-4360.2001 | title = Biotransformation of Malachite Green by the Fungus Cunninghamella elegans | journal = Applied and Environmental Microbiology | volume = 67 | issue = 9 | pages = 4358–4360 | year = 2001 | pmid = 11526047| pmc =93171 }} [[Chitin]]{{Cite journal | last1 = Andrade | first1 = V. S. | last2 = Neto | first2 = B. B. | last3 = Souza | first3 = W. | last4 = Campos-Takaki | first4 = G. M. | title = A factorial design analysis of chitin production byCunninghamella elegans | doi = 10.1139/w00-086 | journal = Canadian Journal of Microbiology | volume = 46 | issue = 11 | pages = 1042–1045 | year = 2000 | pmid = 11109493| pmc = }} and [[chitosan]] isolated from ''C. elegans'' can be used for [[Heavy metal (chemistry)|heavy metal]] [[biosorption]]. Production can be made on yam bean (''[[Pachyrhizus erosus]]'' L. Urban) medium.{{Cite journal | last1 = Montenegro Stamford | first1 = T. C. | last2 = Montenegro Stamford | first2 = T. L. | last3 = Pereira Stamford | first3 = N. | last4 = De Barros Neto | first4 = B. | last5 = De Campos-Takaki | first5 = G. M. | title = Growth of Cunninghamella elegans UCP 542 and production of chitin and chitosan using yam bean medium | doi = 10.2225/vol10-issue1-fulltext-1 | journal = Electronic Journal of Biotechnology | volume = 10 | pages = 0 | year = 2007 | pmid = | pmc = }} ==Strains== ''Cunninghamella elegans'' [[American Type Culture Collection|ATCC]] 9245{{Cite journal | last1 = Zi | first1 = J. | last2 = Valiente | first2 = J. | last3 = Zeng | first3 = J. | last4 = Zhan | first4 = J. | title = Metabolism of quercetin by Cunninghamella elegans ATCC 9245 | doi = 10.1016/j.jbiosc.2011.06.006 | journal = Journal of Bioscience and Bioengineering | volume = 112 | issue = 4 | pages = 360–362 | year = 2011 | pmid = 21742550| pmc = }}
''Cunninghamella elegans'' ATCC 36112{{cite journal |vauthors=Asha S, Vidyavathi M |title=Cunninghamella - a microbial model for drug metabolism studies - a review |journal=Biotechnol. Adv. |volume=27 |issue=1 |pages=16–29 |year=2009 |pmid=18775773 |doi=10.1016/j.biotechadv.2008.07.005 |url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0734-9750(08)00087-6 |accessdate=2009-03-17}}
''Cunninghamella elegans'' ATCC 26269
''Cunninghamella elegans'' [[ARS Culture Collection (NRRL)|NRRL]] 1393
''Cunninghamella elegans'' [[IFM Quality Services Pty Ltd|IFM]] 46109{{Cite journal | last1 = Franco | first1 = L. D. O. | last2 = Maia | first2 = R. D. C. S. C. | last3 = Porto | first3 = A. L. C. F. | last4 = Messias | first4 = A. S. | last5 = Fukushima | first5 = K. | last6 = Campos-Takaki | first6 = G. M. D. | doi = 10.1590/S1517-83822004000200013 | title = Heavy metal biosorption by chitin and chitosan isolated from Cunninghamella elegans (IFM 46109) | journal = Brazilian Journal of Microbiology | volume = 35 | issue = 3 | pages = 243–247 | year = 2004 | pmid = | pmc = }}
''Cunninghamella elegans'' [[Culture Collection of Catholic University of Pernambuco, Recife, Brazil|UCP]] 542{{Cite journal | last1 = Ambrósio | first1 = S. | last2 = Campos-Takaki | first2 = G. M. | title = Decolorization of reactive azo dyes by Cunninghamella elegans UCP 542 under co-metabolic conditions | doi = 10.1016/S0960-8524(03)00153-6 | journal = Bioresource Technology | volume = 91 | issue = 1 | pages = 69–75 | year = 2004 | pmid = 14585623| pmc = }} == References == {{Reflist|32em}} ==External links== * [http://fungalgenomics.concordia.ca/fungi/Cele.php#desc ''Cunninghamella elegans'' on the Fungal Genomics Project] {{Taxonbar|from=Q5194357}} [[Category:Cunninghamellaceae]] [[Category:Fungi described in 1907]] [[Category:Fungal models]] [[Category:Biotechnology]] [[Category:Alternatives to animal testing]]

revision.comment: [[User:JCW-CleanerBot#Logic|task]], replaced: Mini reviews in medicinal chemistry → Mini Reviews in Medicinal Chemistry (2) using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
'''Directed enzyme prodrug therapy''' ('''DEPT''') uses enzymes artificially introduced into the body to convert [[Prodrugs]], which have no or poor biologically activity, to the active form in the desired location within the body.<ref>{{Cite journal|last = Karjoo|first = Zahra|last2 = Chen|first2 = Xuguang|last3 = Hatefi|first3 = Arash|date = 2015-05-22|title = Progress and problems with the use of suicide genes for targeted cancer therapy|journal = Advanced Drug Delivery Reviews|doi = 10.1016/j.addr.2015.05.009|issn = 1872-8294|pmc = 4758904|pmid = 26004498|volume=99|issue = Pt A|pages=113–28}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Zawilska|first=JB|author2=Wojcieszak, J |author3=Olejniczak, AB |title=Prodrugs: A challenge for the drug development.|journal=Pharmacological reports : PR|year=2013|volume=65|issue=1|pages=1–14|pmid=23563019|doi=10.1016/s1734-1140(13)70959-9}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Schellmann|first=N|author2=Deckert, PM |author3=Bachran, D |author4=Fuchs, H |author5= Bachran, C |title=Targeted enzyme prodrug therapies|journal=Mini Reviews in Medicinal Chemistry|date=September 2010|volume=10|issue=10|pages=887–904|pmid=20560876|doi=10.2174/138955710792007196}}</ref> Many [[chemotherapy]] drugs for cancer lack tumour specificity and the doses required to reach therapeutic levels in the tumour are often toxic to other tissues. DEPT strategies are an experimental method of reducing the systemic toxicity of a drug, by achieving high levels of the active drug only at the desired site. This article describes the variations of DEPT technology.
==Antibody-directed enzyme prodrug therapy (ADEPT)== '''ADEPT'''<ref>{{cite journal |author=Bagshawe KD |title=Antibody-directed enzyme prodrug therapy (ADEPT) for cancer |journal=Expert Rev Anticancer Ther |volume=6 |issue=10 |pages=1421–31 |date=October 2006 |pmid=17069527 |doi=10.1586/14737140.6.10.1421 |url=http://www.future-drugs.com/doi/abs/10.1586/14737140.6.10.1421?url_ver=Z39.88-2003&rfr_id=ori:rid:crossref.org&rfr_dat=cr_pub%3dpubmed}}</ref> is a strategy to overcome the problems of lack of [[tumor]] selectivity. An antibody designed/developed against a tumor [[antigen]] is linked to an [[enzyme]] and injected to the blood, resulting in selective binding of the enzyme in the tumor. When the discrimination between tumor and normal tissue enzyme levels is sufficient, a [[prodrug]] is administrated into the blood circulation, which is converted to an active cytotoxic drug by the enzyme, only within the tumor. Selectivity is achieved by the tumor specificity of the antibody and by delaying prodrug administration until there is a large differential between tumor and normal tissue enzyme levels.
ADEPT has shown antitumor activity in animal tumor models of human [[choriocarcinoma]] and colonic and [[breast carcinoma]].
===ADEPT history===
The first pilot-scale clinical trial of ADEPT was carried out at [[Charing Cross Hospital]], [[London]], using an anti-CEA F(ab′)2 antibody conjugated to the bacterial enzyme carboxypeptidase G2 (CPG2).<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Bagshawe KD, Sharma SK, Springer CJ, Antoniw P |title=Antibody directed enzyme prodrug therapy (ADEPT): a pilot scale clinical trial |journal=Tumor Targeting |volume=1 |pages=17–29 |year=1995 }}</ref>
The antibody used in the first ADEPT clinical trial was of murine origin and the enzyme was bacterial. Host antibodies to both components of the AEC were present in the blood of all non-immunosuppressed patients by day 10 after AEC infusion.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Bagshawe KD, Sharma SK |title=Cyclosporine delays host immune response to antibody enzyme conjugate in ADEPT |journal=Transplant. Proc. |volume=28 |issue=6 |pages=3156–8 |date=December 1996 |pmid=8962223 }}</ref> Several patients received [[ciclosporin]] since it had been shown in rabbits that this could delay the appearance of host antibodies to soluble proteins.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1038/bjc.1988.259 |vauthors=Ledermann JA, Begent RH, Bagshawe KD |title=Cyclosporin A prevents the anti-murine antibody response to a monoclonal anti-tumour antibody in rabbits |journal=Br. J. Cancer |volume=58 |issue=5 |pages=562–6 |date=November 1988 |pmid=3265331 |pmc=2246811 }}</ref>
A subsequent, small-scale trial at the [[Royal Free Hospital]], London, used the same agents as in the Charing Cross Hospital trial but the protocol was modified to provide additional pharmacokinetic data and most patients received only a single course of treatment.<ref>KD Bagshawe and M Napier, Early clinical studies with ADEPT. In: RG Melton and RJ Knox Editors, Enzyme-Prodrug Strategies for Cancer Therapy Kluwer Academic, London (1999), 199–207.</ref>
==Gene-directed enzyme prodrug therapy (GDEPT)== {{Expand section|date=May 2013}} GDEPT is a [[suicide gene]] therapy in which the enzyme required for prodrug conversion is produced within the target cell, using a gene delivered to it by gene therapy. When an [[adequate]] differential exists between the targeted cell and endogenous tissue, non-toxic prodrug is administered and is subsequently converted into its toxic form within the target cell.<ref>{{Cite journal|last = Karjoo|first = Zahra|last2 = Chen|first2 = Xuguang|last3 = Hatefi|first3 = Arash|date = 2015-05-22|title = Progress and problems with the use of suicide genes for targeted cancer therapy|journal = Advanced Drug Delivery Reviews|doi = 10.1016/j.addr.2015.05.009|issn = 1872-8294|pmc = 4758904|pmid = 26004498|volume=99|issue = Pt A|pages=113–28}}</ref> Systems that use viral vectors to deliver the gene are known as [[VDEPT]].
==Virus-directed enzyme prodrug therapy (VDEPT)== {{Expand section|date=May 2013}} VDEPT is the term given to the use of a virus to deliver the gene for GDEPT. VDEPT can potentially be used to enhance the therapeutic potential of [[oncolytic viruses]].
== Lectin-directed Enzyme-Activated Prodrug Therapy (LEAPT) == LEAPT is a variant of DEPT in which the manipulation of carbohydrates on the surface of the enzyme is used to target the enzyme activity to the cell in question.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Robinson|first=Mark A.|last2=Charlton|first2=Stuart T.|last3=Garnier|first3=Philippe|last4=Wang|first4=Xiang-tao|last5=Davis|first5=Stanley S.|last6=Perkins|first6=Alan C.|last7=Frier|first7=Malcolm|last8=Duncan|first8=Ruth|last9=Savage|first9=Tony J.|date=2004-10-05|title=LEAPT: Lectin-directed enzyme-activated prodrug therapy|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/101/40/14527|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America|language=en|volume=101|issue=40|pages=14527–14532|doi=10.1073/pnas.0303574101|issn=0027-8424|pmc=521935|pmid=15448212|bibcode=2004PNAS..10114527R}}</ref> This allows exploitation of the sometimes highly specific [[sugar]]-[[lectin]] interactions found in organisms, including humans. Proof-of-principle examples have shown delivery to target organs of enzymes that specifically release cytotoxics to treat tumours.
==Polymer-directed enzyme prodrug therapy (PDEPT)== {{Expand section|date=May 2013}} PDEPT uses [[polymer-drug conjugates]], drugs contained within a polymer 'shell' such as [[pHPMA]] and designed to be released only by a specific enzyme.
==Clostridia-directed enzyme prodrug therapy (CDEPT)== '''CDEPT''' is the use of [[Clostridia]] to convert [[prodrug]]s into active drug agents. CDEPT exploits the [[Tumor hypoxia|hypoxic]] environment of solid tumors to target drugs to tumors using [[anaerobic bacteria]] resident in the tumour to convert the pro-drug to the active form.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Ahn|first=GO|author2=Brown, M|title=Targeting tumors with hypoxia-activated cytotoxins|journal=Frontiers in Bioscience|date=May 1, 2007|volume=12|issue=8–12|pages=3483–501|pmid=17485316|doi=10.2741/2329}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Schellmann|first=N|author2=Deckert, PM |author3=Bachran, D |author4=Fuchs, H |author5= Bachran, C |title=Targeted enzyme prodrug therapies.|journal=Mini Reviews in Medicinal Chemistry|date=September 2010|volume=10|issue=10|pages=887–904|pmid=20560876|doi=10.2174/138955710792007196}}</ref> Intravenously injected clostridial spores exhibit a specificity for tumours, colonising the hypoxic areas of the tumours.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Minton|first=NP|author2=Mauchline, ML |author3=Lemmon, MJ |author4=Brehm, JK |author5=Fox, M |author6=Michael, NP |author7=Giaccia, A |author8= Brown, JM |title=Chemotherapeutic tumour targeting using clostridial spores.|journal=FEMS Microbiology Reviews|date=October 1995|volume=17|issue=3|pages=357–64|pmid=7576773|doi=10.1111/j.1574-6976.1995.tb00219.x}}</ref>
=== The CDEPT strategy ===
Perhaps the most challenging issue in [[cancer treatment]] is how to reduce the side effects of the injected anti-cancer agents, which are of a high [[cytotoxicity]] potential. A widely used solution is to use [[enzyme]]s which are able to convert a relatively non-toxic prodrug precursor into the active drug form(s). Clostridial-directed enzyme prodrug therapy (CDEPT)<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1574-6976.1995.tb00219.x |vauthors=Minton NP, Mauchline ML, Lemmon MJ, etal |title=Chemotherapeutic tumour targeting using clostridial spores |journal=FEMS Microbiol. Rev. |volume=17 |issue=3 |pages=357–64 |date=October 1995 |pmid=7576773 }}</ref> is one of the possible approaches.
Solid [[tumor]]s, in contrast to normal tissues, grow rapidly. As a result, the cancerous tissues may suffer from inadequate [[blood]] and [[oxygen]] supply.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1097/00001813-200202000-00002 |vauthors=Nuyts S, Van Mellaert L, Theys J, Landuyt W, Lambin P, Anné J |title=Clostridium spores for tumor-specific drug delivery |journal=Anticancer Drugs |volume=13 |issue=2 |pages=115–25 |date=February 2002 |pmid=11901303 |url=http://meta.wkhealth.com/pt/pt-core/template-journal/lwwgateway/media/landingpage.htm?issn=0959-4973&volume=13&issue=2&spage=115}}</ref> Therefore, clostridia can grow in tumor and destroy it specifically.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Brown JM, Wilson WR |title=Exploiting tumour hypoxia in cancer treatment |journal=Nat. Rev. Cancer |volume=4 |issue=6 |pages=437–47 |date=June 2004 |pmid=15170446 |doi=10.1038/nrc1367}}</ref> (Originally, Parker and co-workers<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Parker RC, Plumber HC, Siebenmann CO, Chapman MG |title=Effect of histolyticus infection and toxin on transplantable mouse tumours |journal=Proc. Soc. Exp. Biol. Med. |volume=66 |pages=461–5 |year=1947 |doi=10.3181/00379727-66-16124}}</ref> showed that the injection of ''Clostridium histolyticum'' spores to the transplanted sarcomas of mice results in significant tumour lysis. Soon after, it was shown that a direct injection is not necessary, and that tumour colonization was readily obtained after intravenous administration of spores<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Malmgren RA, Flanigan CC |title=Localization of the vegetative form of ''Clostridium tetani'' in mouse tumors following intravenous spore administration |journal=Cancer Res. |volume=15 |issue=7 |pages=473–8 |date=August 1955 |pmid=13240693 |url=http://cancerres.aacrjournals.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=13240693}}</ref>).
In CDEPT, a prodrug-converting enzyme expressed by a clostridial expression plasmid converts a prodrug into an active drug form within the tumor. While the prodrug is the inactive form and can be administrated to the blood, the products of the prodrug cleavage are highly cytotoxic and show their effect only in the vicinity of tumor cells.
Difficulties in the engineering of clostridial strains have restricted the application of other enzyme prodrug systems. So far, two enzymes have been applied in CDEPT: [[cytosine deaminase]] and [[nitroreductase]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=Minton NP |title=Clostridia in cancer therapy |journal=Nat. Rev. Microbiol. |volume=1 |issue=3 |pages=237–42 |date=December 2003 |pmid=15035028 |doi=10.1038/nrmicro777}}</ref> It has been recently suggested that [[β-lactamase]]s, which are naturally found in Clostridia, can facilitate the application of the method significantly.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Tirandaz H, Hamedi J, Marashi SA |title=Application of beta-lactamase-dependent prodrugs in clostridial-directed enzyme therapy (CDEPT): a proposal |journal=Med. Hypotheses |volume=67 |issue=4 |pages=998–9 |year=2006 |pmid=16797858 |doi=10.1016/j.mehy.2006.05.008 |url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0306-9877(06)00340-9}}</ref>{{ums|date=November 2017}}
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Experimental cancer treatments]] [[Category:Biotechnology]]

Pictures]] | released = {{film date|2011|08|04|[[Fantasia Film Festival]]|2011|08|12|United States}} | runtime = 92 minutes<!-- Theatrical runtime: 91:41 --><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/AFF279025/ | title=''Final Destination 5'' | publisher=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=2011-07-29 | accessdate=2011-07-31}}</ref> | country = United States | language = English | budget = $40 million<ref name="BOM">{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=finaldestination5.htm |title=Final Destination 5 (2011) |publisher= [[Box Office Mojo]] |date=2011-08-02 |accessdate=2011-08-29}}</ref> | gross = $157.9 million<ref name="BOM" /> }} '''''Final Destination 5''''' is a 2011 American [[3D film|3D]] [[supernatural horror film]] directed by [[Steven Quale]] and is the fifth installment of the [[Final Destination|''Final Destination'' film series]]. It was written by [[Eric Heisserer]] and stars [[Nicholas D'Agosto]], [[Emma Bell]], [[Miles Fisher]], [[Arlen Escarpeta]], [[David Koechner]] and [[Tony Todd]].
Despite [[The Final Destination|the previous film]] being originally announced as the final of the franchise, due to its financial success, development of ''Final Destination 5'' began in 2010. Filming took place in [[Vancouver]], as with the first three installments. It was theatrically released in August 12, 2011, and on [[DVD]] on December 27, 2011, which includes deleted scenes, documentaries and a parody music video by the cast.
The film received mostly positive reviews; the first film in the franchise to do so. Critics praised the plot, CGI, death scenes and tone, especially in comparison to the previous installment. The film was a financial success and is the second-highest-grossing film in the franchise.
==Plot==
In April 2000, Sam Lawton is on his way to a company retreat with his colleagues. While their bus crosses the North Bay Bridge, Sam has a premonition that the bridge will collapse, killing everyone except his ex-girlfriend Molly Harper, whom he manages to get across the bridge safely. In a panic, he persuades several people to leave the bridge before it collapses, including Molly, his friends Nathan Sears and Peter Friedkin, Peter's girlfriend Candice Hooper, his boss Dennis Lapman, and his co-workers Olivia Castle and Isaac Palmer. FBI agent Jim Block doesn't believe that Sam is responsible for the bridge collapse, but promises to keep an eye on him. At the memorial service, coroner William Bludworth mysteriously tells the survivors that "Death doesn't like to be cheated" and warns them to be careful. However, they ignore his warning and leave, believing this to be nonsense.
Later, Candice goes to the gym to practice with Peter, but a chain reaction causes her to fly off the uneven bars, and she snaps her spine, leaving Peter devastated. The next day, Isaac is killed at a Chinese spa when his head is crushed by a falling Buddha statue during an acupuncture session. Bludworth, who has been present for both deaths, tells the remaining survivors that if they wish to cheat Death, they must kill someone who was never meant to die on the bridge and thereby claim their remaining lifespan. On the same day, Olivia goes to an eye surgery clinic to treat her myopic vision. While the doctor is away looking for files, the laser malfunctions, searing her eye and hand. She manages to free herself just as Sam and Molly arrive to save her, but trips and falls out of the window onto a car below. Later, Sam learns that the survivors are dying in the order they were meant to die on the bridge, and realize that Nathan is next.
Meanwhile, Nathan, who has returned to the factory, accidentally kills his co-worker, Roy Carson, during an argument by pushing him in front of a lifting hook, which impales him through the chin. As Nathan informs the remaining survivors about this, they realize he claimed Roy's remaining lifespan by killing him, and therefore must be safe. When Dennis arrives to question Nathan about the incident, a wrench launched by a belt sander hits him in the face, killing him.
That evening, after working at a restaurant, Sam asks his supervisor to reserve the restaurant for a date with Molly. Peter, who has become unstable after Candice's death, interrupts the date and tells them that he will kill Molly to take her lifespan. After Peter draws a gun, Sam and Molly both escape to the kitchen. Agent Block overhears the gunshots from outside. When he enters the restaurant, he is shot dead by Peter. Believing that he is safe from Death, Peter decides to kill both Molly and Sam to remove any witnesses. The two men fight and Peter knocks Sam unconscious. Just as Peter is about to stab Molly with a kitchen knife, Sam awakens and stabs him in the back with a large skewer, leading Sam to believe he has claimed Block's life.
Two weeks later, Sam and Molly board a plane to Paris. As they take their seats, a fight breaks out between two passengers, Alex Browning and Carter Horton, revealing the plane he and Molly are on is Flight 180. Upon take-off, Sam overhears that Alex had a vision of the plane's destruction, but it's too late, and both he and Molly are killed when the plane explodes. At Roy's memorial, Nathan learns that Roy had a brain aneurysm that would have burst "any day now". As Nathan realizes he may still be in danger, the landing gear from Flight 180 breaks through the roof and crushes him.
==Cast== :''For more details on the characters, see [[List of Final Destination characters]].'' {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Nicholas D'Agosto]] as [[Sam Lawton]] * [[Emma Bell]] as [[List of Final Destination characters#Molly Harper|Molly Harper]] * [[Miles Fisher]] as [[List of Final Destination characters#Peter Friedkin|Peter Friedkin]] * Ellen Wroe as [[List of Final Destination characters#Candice Hooper|Candice Hooper]] * [[Jacqueline MacInnes Wood]] as [[Olivia Castle]] * [[P. J. Byrne]] as [[List of Final Destination characters#Isaac Palmer|Isaac Palmer]] * [[Arlen Escarpeta]] as [[List of Final Destination characters#Nathan Sears|Nathan Sears]] * [[David Koechner]] as [[List of Final Destination characters#Dennis Lapman|Dennis Lapman]] * [[Courtney B. Vance]] as [[List of Final Destination characters#Agent Jim Block|Agent Jim Block]] * [[Tony Todd]] as [[William Bludworth]] * [[Brent Stait]] as [[List of Final Destination characters#Roy Carson|Roy Carson]] * [[Chasty Ballesteros]] as Spa receptionist {{div col end}}
==Production==
===Development=== [[File:Nicholas D'Agosto filming Final Destination 5 in Vancouver, October 2010.jpg|thumb|150px|D'Agosto while filming ''Final Destination 5'' in Vancouver, October 2010]] [[Alan Horn]], the head of [[Warner Bros.]], confirmed at [[ShoWest]] in March 2010 that ''Final Destination 5'' was in works at ShoWest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/showestnews.php?id=64384|title=ShoWest 2010: A Fifth Final Destination is Coming |publisher=[[ComingSoon.net]] | date=March 18, 2010}}</ref> Producer Craig Perry later added that the film would be shot in [[3D film|3D]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/19536|title=Producer Talks Fifth 'Final Destination' in 3-D |publisher=[[Bloody-Disgusting.com]] | date=March 21, 2010}}</ref> [[Eric Heisserer]] was announced as screenwriter in April 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://reporter.blogs.com/comiccon/page/11/ |title='The Thing' writer boards 'Final Destination 5' (exclusive) |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=April 25, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60ols9d5R?url=http://reporter.blogs.com/comiccon/page/11/ |archivedate=August 9, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} (requires scrolldown)</ref> The studio initially picked August 26, 2011, as the release date<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=66026|title=Soderbergh's Contagion Contaminates 2011 in 3D! |publisher=[[ComingSoon.net]] | date=May 14, 2010}}</ref> but later changed it to August 12, 2011.<ref name=newrelease>{{cite web |url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/24323 |title=A Nice Change Of Pace: 'Apollo 18' And 'Final Destination 5' Move Up| first=David|last=Harley|date=April 27, 2011|publisher=[[Bloody-Disgusting.com]]}}</ref> In June 2010, [[New Line Cinema]] announced that Steven Quale would direct.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118020369?refCatId=13|first=Dave|last=McNary|title=Quale flies to 'Final Destination 5'|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | date=June 8, 2010}}</ref>
===Writing=== According to Heisserer, ''Final Destination 5'' was always meant to be a [[prequel]], set before the first film; the idea having come from franchise producer Craig Perry. Heisserer said that one major problem he encountered while writing the film was coming up with good death sequences, believing that managing to do so in the world of ''Final Destination'' is "ridiculously hard". The inspiration for Olivia's death sequence involving [[LASIK]] [[eye surgery]] after his wife underwent the same type of surgery.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Thurman|first1=Trace|title=Taking the Blame: An Interview With Screenwriter Eric Heisserer!|url=http://bloody-disgusting.com/interviews/3397692/eric-heisserer-interview/|publisher=[[Bloody Disgusting]]|accessdate=29 May 2017|date=20 July 2016}}</ref>
===Casting=== In August 2010, actor and musician [[Miles Fisher]] was the first to be cast in the film as Peter Friedkin.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2010/08/pinkberry-dealmaker-miles-fisher-lands-real-movie-job/|title='Pinkberry' Actor Miles Fisher Lands Movie|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |first=Mike|last=Fleming| date=August 13, 2010}}</ref> Fisher had appeared in numerous short films and in a small role in the comedy film ''[[Superhero Movie]]'' (2008). Fisher said during an interview that "I've done a little bit of television and a little bit of film, but 3-D is almost an entirely different sport."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/entertainment/movies/headlines/20110812-dallas-native-stars-in-final-destination-5.ece|title=Dallas native stars in ‘Final Destination 5’|publisher=[[Dallasnews.com]] |first=Gary|last=Dowell| date=August 12, 2010}}</ref> Three days after Fisher's casting, [[Arlen Escarpeta]] was cast in the film as Nathan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://movies.about.com/b/2010/08/15/arlen-escarpeta-joins-final-destination-5.htm|first=Rebecca|last=Murray|title=Arlen Escarpeta Joins ''Final Destination 5''|publisher=[[About.com]]|date=August 15, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100819123822/http://movies.about.com/b/2010/08/15/arlen-escarpeta-joins-final-destination-5.htm|archivedate=August 19, 2010|df=}}</ref> Escarpeta explained that "I think what they're going to do really, really well this time around, they're going to go back—the story, the plot, a lot of stuff is really going to matter, I think the last movie it was just death. It was death, death, death, which is fine because that's what people want to see. But this time we're going to give them a little bit of everything – good story, great director—it's going to be good."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://movies.about.com/b/2010/08/15/arlen-escarpeta-joins-final-destination-5.htm|title=Arlen Escarpeta Joins Final Destination 5|publisher=[[About.com]]|first=Rebecca|last=Murray|date=August 15, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100819123822/http://movies.about.com/b/2010/08/15/arlen-escarpeta-joins-final-destination-5.htm|archivedate=August 19, 2010|df=}}</ref> He appeared in the films ''[[American Gun (2005 film)|American Gun]]'' (2005) and ''[[Friday the 13th (2009 film)|Friday the 13th]]'' (2009). In late August 2010 [[Nicholas D'Agosto]] and Ellen Wroe were cast.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/21439|title=What's That? I Hear Death Calling New 'Final Destination 5' Victims!|publisher=[[Bloody-Disgusting.com]] | date=August 25, 2010}}</ref> One day later, [[Tony Todd]], who portrayed [[William Bludworth]] from the first two installments joined the film.<ref name="bloody-disgusting1">{{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/21452|title=Tony Todd Returns as the Reaper in 'Final Destination 5'|publisher=[[Bloody-Disgusting.com]] | date=August 26, 2010}}</ref>
On August 30, 2010, [[David Koechner]] and [[P. J. Byrne]] were announced to have joined the cast.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2010/08/31/film-us-final-idUKTRE67U0X820100831 |title='Final Destination 5' adds four to cast |first=Borys |last=Kit |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] via [[Reuters]] |date=August 31, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60opcKBPl?url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2010/08/31/film-us-final-idUKTRE67U0X820100831 |archivedate=August 9, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> On September 2, [[Emma Bell]] was cast as the female lead; Molly.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.joblo.com/arrow/index.php?id=23869|title=EXCLUSIVE: Emma Bell cast as the lead in Final Destination 5 aka 5nal Destination!|publisher=[[Joblo.com]] | date=September 2, 2010}}</ref> In mid-September both [[Jacqueline MacInnes Wood]] and [[Courtney B. Vance]] joined the main cast.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://movies.about.com/b/2010/09/21/final-destination-5-3d-starts-filming-in-vancouver.htm |title='FD5 Begins filming & Official cast released|publisher=[[About.com]] | date=September 25, 2010}}</ref>
===Filming=== [[Image:Lions' Gate Bridge (from Stanley Park).jpg|thumb|right|The opening scene featuring the North Bay Bridge collapse in North Bay, [[New York (state)|New York]], [[United States]] was filmed on the [[Lions' Gate Bridge]] in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], [[Canada]] and two scale representations of the bridge]] Location filming returned to [[Vancouver]], where parts of the first three films were shot. [[Principal photography]] took place between September 13 and December 14, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bcfilmcommission.com/about_us/film_list.php|title=BCFC Film List|publisher=British Columbia Film Commission|date=October 2, 2011|accessdate=October 2, 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101027000000/http://www.bcfilmcommission.com/database/rte/files/Film%20List%20-%20October%2026%2C%202010.pdf|archivedate=October 27, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> Producers stated that this installment would be darker and more suspenseful in the style of the [[Final Destination (film)|original film]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://shocktillyoudrop.com/news/topnews.php?id=14556|title=Producer's Update on Final Destination 5...|publisher=ShockTillYouDrop.com|first= Ryan (pseudonym)|last= Rotten|date=March 21, 2010|accessdate=May 22, 2011}}</ref> ''[[Final Destination 3]]'' star [[Chelan Simmons]] revealed that the opening scene would be filmed on the [[Lions Gate Bridge]] in Vancouver.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/ChelanLSimmons/status/27307831744 |title= Final Destination Fans this is the Bridge FD5 will take place on!!!! Ps. It'll be in 3D! |publisher=Twitter.com |date=2010-10-14 |accessdate=2011-05-09}}</ref>
==Music== ===Soundtrack===
The soundtrack to ''Final Destination 5'' was released physically on August 16, 2011, four days after the release of the film. The soundtrack contains 19 tracks composed by [[Brian Tyler (composer)|Brian Tyler]], music composer of ''[[The Final Destination]]''. It is also the second ''[[Final Destination]]'' soundtrack album to be released. Miles Fisher also released a tie-in video for his single "New Romance" which features the key actors in the film in a ''[[Saved by the Bell]]'' parody in which most are killed in freak accidents, in keeping with the series.
